Sisters was an American television drama series. The show was about four sisters in Winnetka, Illinois.

The show was first broadcast in May of 1991. It lasted until May 4, 1996.

[[World Almanac]]

CATEGORIES: Reference works

The World Almanac and Book of Facts is a reference book. It has information on tragedies, sports, weather and celebrities. The book was #1 on the Washington Post bestseller list in November 2011.

The book has been published every year since 1868, except between 1876 and 1885.

Rosie Perez reads the book in White Men Can't Jump.

[[Gunnar Hultgren]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 births, 1991 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Gunnar Hultgren (19 February 1902, Eskilstuna, Sweden – 13 February 1991, Uppsala, Sweden) was a Swedish bishop. He was active within the Church of Sweden. He was the Archbishop of Uppsala between 1958 and 1967.

[[Ruben Josefson]]

CATEGORIES: 1907 births, 1972 deaths, Swedish clergy, Archbishops of Uppsala

Ruben Josefson (25 August 1907, Svenljunga, Sweden – 19 March 1972, Uppsala, Sweden) was a Swedish bishop. He was active within the Church of Sweden.. He was the Archbishop of Uppsala between 1967-1972.

[[Olof Sundby]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 1996 deaths, Swedish clergy, Archbishops of Uppsala

Olof Sundby (6 December 1917, Karlskoga, Sweden – 6 December 1996 in Lund, Sweden) was a Swedish bishop. He was active within the Church of Sweden.. He was the Archbishop of Uppsala between 1972 and 1983.

[[Hans Olof Holmström]]

CATEGORIES: 1784 births, 1855 deaths, Swedish clergy, Archbishops of Uppsala

Hans Olof Holmström (15 October 1784, Ösmno Parish, Sweden – 27 August 1855 in Uppsala, Sweden) was a Swedish bishop. He was active within the Church of Sweden.. He was the Archbishop of Uppsala between 1852-1855.

[[Anja Pärson]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Swedish skiers, 1981 births, LGBT rights activists, LGBT sportspeople, Lesbians, Medalists at the 2006 Winter Olympics, Medalists at the 2010 Winter Olympics, Olympic bronze medalists, Olympic gold medalists, Olympic silver medalists, Swedish Olympians, Swedish sportspeople

Anja Sofia Tess Pärson (ˌanjaˈpæːʂɔn; born 25 April 1981) in Tärnaby, Sweden is a Swedish former alpine skier. She won several Olympic titles and World Championship titles. In 2003 and 2004, she also won the total Alpine Skiing World Cup. Totally, she won 42 World Cup events.

[[Magdalena Forsberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, Swedish skiers

Magdalena "Magda" Forsberg (born 25 July 1967 in Ullånger, Sweden as Magdalena Wallin) is a Swedish former cross country skier and biathlete. She won the overall Biathlon World Cup for six years straight between the seasons of 1996-1997 and 2001/2002. She also won several Biathlon World Championships titles. She also participated in the Cross-Country Skiing World Cup between the seasons of 1987/1988 and 1995/1996. Her best results at the Winter Olympics were in Albertville in 1992 where she finished seventh in the 4 × 5 km relay and 26th in the 15 km event.

[[Charlotte Kalla]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people, Swedish skiers

Marina Charlotte Kalla (born 22 July 1987 in Tärendö, Sweden) is a Swedish cross-country skier. She has competed at the international level since the 2003-2004 season. She won a bronze medal at the women's 4 x 5 kilometre relay event during the FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2009 in Liberec in the Czech Republic.

On 6 January 2008, she won the second edition of the Tour de Ski event.

On 6 May 2012, she signed for Piteå Elit for the 2012/2013 season.

[[Antje Jackelén]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, Archbishops of Uppsala, German Lutherans, People from North Rhine-Westphalia, Swedish clergy

Antje Jackelén, born 4 June 1955 in Herdecke, North Rhine-Westphalia, West Germany, is the Protestant (Lutheran) archbishop of Uppsala in Sweden. She is primate (prima inter pares) of the Church of Sweden. On 15 October 2013, she was elected the 70th Archbishop of Uppsala. She was formally received through a service inside the Uppsala Cathedral on 15 June 2014. This made her the Church of Sweden's first archbishop to be born outside Sweden since the 12th century. She also became the denomination's first female archbishop.

[[Ingemar Stenmark]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, 1988 Winter Olympics, Olympic bronze medalists, Olympic gold medalists, Swedish Olympians, Swedish skiers

Jan Ingemar Stenmark (ˈɪŋɛmar ˈsteːnmark), born 18 March 1956 in Joesjö, Sweden  is a Swedish former Alpine World Cup skier. He competed at international level between the early 1970s and the late 1980s. He won several titles during the World Championship titles, the Olympic Games and the World Cup.

[[Duke of Bedford]]

CATEGORIES: English Dukes

The title of Duke of Bedford is a British title has been created several times and is today held by the Russell family since 1694. The heir to the title is usually given the title of "Marquess of Tavistock". The family seat is Woburn Abbey, Bedfordshire. The private mausoleum and chapel of the Russell Family and the Dukes of Bedford is at St. Michael’s Church in Chenies, Buckinghamshire. The family owns the Bedford Estate in central London. The duke is entitled to the style of address of His/Your Grace. 

[[Gunde Svan]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, Swedish skiers

Gunde Svan, born 12 January 1962 in Dala-Järna, Sweden is a Swedish former cross-country skier and auto racing driver. As a cross-country skier he won several titles during the World Championship titles and the Olympic Games as well the World Cup.

[[Christine McVie]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, British singer-songwriters, Keyboardists, People from Cumbria

Christine McVie (born Christine Anne Perfect on 12 July 1943) is an English singer-songwriter and keyboardist. She is best known for being a member of rock band Fleetwood Mac. Eight songs written and sung by McVie are on the band's Greatest Hits album. They include "Don't Stop", "Little Lies", "Everywhere" and "You Make Loving Fun". She has also released three solo albums.

In 1998, as a member of Fleetwood Mac, McVie was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. She also received the Brit Award for Outstanding Contribution to Music. After retiring from the band, she worked on solo material. McVie appeared on stage with Fleetwood Mac at London's O2 Arena in September 2013. She rejoined the band in January 2014. Her first full shows since her return were during Fleetwood Mac's On with the Show tour in October 2014. In 2014, McVie received the British Academy's Ivor Novello Award for Lifetime Achievement.

[[We Were Gentlemen]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 establishments in the United States, 2010 disestablishments in the United States, 2000s American music groups, 2010s American music groups, Metalcore bands, Musical groups disestablished in 2010, Musical groups established in 2005, Musical groups from Virginia, Virginia Beach, Virginia

We Were Gentlemen is an American metalcore band. It formed in 2005 in Virginia Beach, Virginia. They split in 2010.

[[Lorimar-Telepictures]]

CATEGORIES: Time Warner, Companies based in Los Angeles

Lorimar-Telepictures was an entertainment company established on April 21, 1986 with the merger of Lorimar and Telepictures. Its assets included television production and syndication (which operated under the Lorimar-Telepictures name), feature films, home video, and broadcasting.

[[Qayyum Chowdhury]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2014 deaths, Bangladeshi painters

Qayyum Chowdhury (কাইয়ুম চৌধুরী, March 9, 1932 – November 30, 2014) was a Bangladeshi painter. He was known for painting cover photos. He painted covers for over 26 years. His works can be seen all over Bangladesh.

On November 30, 2014, Chowdhury fell sick while delivering his speech on the fourth-day of Bengal Foundation organized classical music festival in Bangladesh Army Stadium. He was rushed to CMH, where on-duty doctor declared him dead. He was 82 years old.

[[Dwayne Alons]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from kidney cancer, Politicians from Iowa, State legislators of the United States, US Republican Party politicians

Dwayne Arlan Alons (October 30, 1946 – November 29, 2014) was an American politician. He was the Iowa State Representative from the 4th District. He was a member of the Republican party. Alons served in the Iowa House of Representatives since 1999. He was a Brigadier General in the Iowa Air National Guard and served as Chief of Staff at its headquarters.

Alons died of kidney cancer on November 29, 2014 in Sioux Center, Iowa, aged 68.

[[Joan Feynman]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, American astronomers, Scientists from Queens

Joan Feynman (March 31, 1927 – July 22, 2020)  was an American astrophysicist. Her work focused on solar wind particles and fields; sun-Earth relations; and magnetospheric physics. Feynman was the younger sister of physicist Richard Feynman who, since they were children, encouraged her interest in nature.

Feynman died on July 22, 2020 in Oxnard, California from heart failure at the age of 93.

[[El Chavo del Ocho]]

CATEGORIES: Mexican television series, Sitcoms, 1970s television series debuts, 1971 establishments, 1970s establishments in Mexico, 1980 disestablishments, 20th century disestablishments in Mexico, 1980s disestablishments in North America

El Chavo del Ocho is a very popular Mexican sitcom. It was created and written by Roberto Gómez Bolaños. It stars Roberto Gómez Bolaños, María Antonieta de las Nieves, Carlos Villagrán, Florinda Meza, Ramón Valdés, Rubén Aguirre, Édgar Vivar, Raúl Padilla, Horacio Gómez Bolaños, and Angelines Fernández. It ran from 1971 through 1980 for 8 seasons.

El Chapulín Colorado (English: The Red Grasshopper) is a Mexican television comedy series. It was created and written by Roberto Gómez Bolaños. It ran from 1973 to 1979.

[[Chespirito (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: Mexican television series, Sitcoms, 1968 television series debuts, 1960s establishments in Mexico, 1973 television series endings, 1970s disestablishments in North America, 20th century disestablishments in Mexico, 1980 television series debuts, 1980 establishments, 1980s establishments in Mexico, 1995 television series endings, 1990s disestablishments in North America

Chespirito, also known as Los Supergenios de la Mesa Cuadrada from 1968–1970 and Chespirito y la Mesa Cuadrada from 1970-1971, is a Mexican sketch comedy show. It aired in Mexico for two periods, 1968–1973 and 1980-1995. The program aired various sketches of characters created by Roberto Gómez Bolaños.

[[Florinda Meza]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican screenwriters, Television producers, People from Zacatecas

Florinda Meza García (born 8 February 1949) is a Mexican actress, television producer, and screenwriter. She is best known as Doña Florinda in El Chavo del Ocho, La Chimoltrufia in Chespirito, and other various roles in El Chapulín Colorado.

Meza was married to Roberto Gómez Bolaños from 2004 until his death in 2014.

[[María Antonieta de las Nieves]]

María Antonieta Gómez Rodríguez (born 22 December 1949), more commonly known by her stage name María Antonieta de las Nieves, is a Mexican actress, comedienne, and singer. She is known for her role as La Chilindrina in the Mexican sitcom El Chavo del Ocho.

[[Carlos Villagrán]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican comedians, Mexican journalists, Actors from Mexico City

Carlos Villagrán Eslava (born 12 January 1944) is a Mexican actor, comedian, and former journalist. He is best known for playing Quico in the Televisa sitcom El Chavo del Ocho and the Telerey sitcom ¡Ah qué Kiko!.

[[Ramón Valdés]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 1988 deaths, Actors from Mexico City, Cancer deaths in Mexico, Deaths from stomach cancer, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors

Ramón Gómez Valdés de Castillo (September 2, 1923 – August 9, 1988), often credited as Ramón Valdéz, was a Mexican actor. He was best known for his role of Don Ramón in the popular sitcom El Chavo del Ocho. He was born in Mexico City, Mexico.

Valdés died in Mexico City from stomach cancer, aged 64.

[[Rubén Aguirre]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2016 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Coahuila, People from Monterrey

Rubén Aguirre Fuentes (ruˈβen aˈɣire; June 15, 1934 – June 17, 2016) was a Mexican actor. He was best remembered for his role as Professor Jirafales in the Televisa's television show El Chavo del Ocho.

Aguirre died on June 17, 2016 at his home in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. He died from complications of pneumonia, justt two days after his 82nd birthday. He suffered from diabetes which has been said to also been a factor to his death.

[[Édgar Vivar]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Actors from Mexico City

Dr. Édgar Ángel Vivar Villanueva (born December 28, 1944) is a Mexican actor. He is best remembered as "Señor Barriga" and his son "Ñoño" from El Chavo del Ocho, and as "El Botija" from El Chapulín Colorado and in Chespirito.

[[Raúl Padilla]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 1994 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Disease-related deaths in Mexico, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, People from Monterrey

Raúl "Chato" Padilla Mendoza (June 17, 1917 – February 3, 1994) was a Mexican actor. He was known for his role as Jaimito el Cartero ("Jaimito, the Mailman") in El Chavo del Ocho. His nickname "Chato" means "Pug" because he had a flat nose and it looked like a pug.

Padilla died in Mexico City, Mexico from a heart attack, aged 76.

[[Pecan pie]]

CATEGORIES: Pies, Desserts

Pecan pies are sweet pies. They are made mostly with corn syrup and pecans. Some are made with brown sugar, molasses or honey. 

Pecan pie is often served in the Southern United States with Thanksgiving and Christmas meals.

[[Horacio Gómez Bolaños]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 1999 deaths, Actors from Mexico City, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Mexico, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Mexican comedians, Mexican movie actors, Mexican movie directors, Mexican screenwriters, Mexican television actors

Horacio Gómez Bolaños (June 28, 1930 - November 21, 1999) was a Mexican actor. He was the brother of Roberto Gómez Bolaños. On the TV show El Chavo del 8, he played the character Godinez. 

Bolaños died on November 21, 1999 of a heart attack during the production of a tribute to Chespirito for Televisa, aged 69.

[[Angelines Fernández]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 1994 deaths, Actors from Madrid, Cancer deaths in Mexico, Deaths from throat cancer, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Spanish movie actors, Spanish television actors

María de los Ángeles "Angelines" Fernández Abad (9 July 1922 – 25 March 1994) was a Spanish-born Mexican actress. She was best remembered for playing Doña Clotilde "La Bruja del 71" in the Televisa sitcom El Chavo del Ocho. She was born in Madrid, Spain.

Fernández died from throat cancer in Mexico City, Mexico, aged 71.

[[Gustavo Díaz Ordaz]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 1979 deaths, Cancer deaths in Mexico, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Presidents of Mexico

Gustavo Díaz Ordaz Bolaños (gusˈtaβo ˈðias orˈðas; 12 March 1911 – 15 July 1979) was a Mexican politician. He was a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI). He served as the President of Mexico from 1964 to 1970. His distant cousin was comedian Roberto Gomez Bolaños.

Ordaz died in Mexico City, Mexico on 15 July 1979 from colorectal cancer, aged 68.

[[Jean-Jacques Perrey]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2016 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, French composers, Musicians from Paris

Jean-Jacques Perrey (pɛʁɛ; January 20, 1929 – November 4, 2016) was a French electronic music producer. He was best known for writing electronic music. He worked with the duo Perrey and Kingsley. He was also known for producing the them "The Elephant Never Forgets".

Perrey died from complications of lung cancer in Switzerland,  aged 87.

[[Go Seigen]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Chinese sportspeople, Japanese Go players, Japanese centenarians

Wu Qingyuan (吳清源; June 12, 1914 – November 30, 2014), also known as Go Seigen, was a Japanese Go player. 

He was thought by many other Go players as one of the greatest Go players in its history. Seigen turned 100 in June 2014. Seigen was born in Fuzhou, Fujian, China.

Seigen died in Odawara, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan from natural causes, aged 100.

[[Óscar Humberto Mejía Victores]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2016 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Presidents of Guatemala, People from Guatemala City

Brigadier General Óscar Humberto Mejía Victores (December 9, 1930 – February 1, 2016) was a Guatemalan politician. He was the 27th President of Guatemala from 8 August 1983 to 14 January 1986. 

Victores died in Guatemala City from Parkinson's disease on February 1, 2016 at the age of 85.

[[Álvaro Arzú]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Presidents of Guatemala, Mayors, People from Guatemala City

Álvaro Enrique Arzú Yrigoyen (14 March 1946 – 27 April 2018) was a Guatemalan politician. He was the 32nd President of Guatemala from January 14, 1996 until January 14, 2000. He was elected Mayor of Guatemala City five times and served his fifth term from 2004 until his death in 2018.

On April 27, 2018, Arzú suffered a heart attack while playing golf with his son in Guatemala City. He died in the hospital later that day.

[[Óscar Berger]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, Presidents of Guatemala, People from Guatemala City

Óscar José Rafael Berger Perdomo (born 11 August 1946 in Guatemala City) is a Guatemalan politician. He served as President of Guatemala serving from 2004 through 2008.

[[Monosodium glutamate]]

CATEGORIES: Sodium compounds

Monosodium glutamate (MSG), also known as sodium glutamate, is the sodium salt of glutamic acid. It is a chemical used to make foods taste better. This works because savory flavors are enhanced. That means the savory flavors are stronger. MSG is found in most foods. It is in higher concentrations in high protein foods such as meat, fish and dairy products. It has the E number of 621. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has classed MSG as a food additive that is "generally recognized as safe". However, the FDA requires that it be listed on the label.

[[Sergio Corona]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican voice actors, Mexican comedians, Hidalgo (state)

Sergio Corona Ortega (born October 7, 1928) is a Mexican television and movie actor and comedian. He has appeared in over 50 telenovelas. Corona is known for his roles as Don Tomas Leon in the Mexican telenovela Come dice el dicho and as Don Boni in Plaza Sésamo (Spanish version of Sesame Street). He also appeared as a bellboy in the 1989 James Bond movie License to Kill.

Corona was born in Pachuca, Hidalgo, Mexico.

[[Aqueous solution]]

CATEGORIES: Chemistry

An aqueous solution is a solution where the solvent is water. In a chemical equation it is written by adding (aq) to the formula. A solution of ordinary table salt in water would be written as NaCl(aq). NaCl is the part that means table salt. The word aqueous means being dissolved in water. Water is a solvent. It is found all over the place. Water is a solvent in chemistry.

[[Luc De Vos]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2014 deaths, Belgian musicians, Belgian singers, Belgian voice actors, Belgian writers, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Disease-related deaths in Belgium, People from East Flanders, Rock guitarists, Rock singers

Luc De Vos (12 July 1962 – 29 November 2014) was a Belgian musician and writer. He was best known as the lead singer of the Alternative Dutch language rock group Gorki. He also voiced Fillmore in the Flemish version of the Disney movie Cars. He was born in Evergem, Belgium.

Vos died from acute multiple organ failure in Ghent, Belgium, aged 52.

[[2014 India-Pakistan floods]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 disasters, 2014 in India, 2010s disasters in Asia, 2010s floods, 2010s in Pakistan, Floods in India, Floods in Pakistan, Jammu and Kashmir, September 2014 events

From 2-26 September 2014, the Kashmir region of South Asia witnessed heavy floods across a large part of its districts. This was caused by heavy rainfall. In Jammu & Kashmir in India, as well as Azad Kashmir, Gilgit-Baltistan and Punjab in Pakistan, were affected by these floods. 566 people died due to the floods in this area.

[[Mother (Gorky Novel)]]

CATEGORIES: Russian novels

Mother (Mat') is a novel written by Maxim Gorky in 1906. It is about an uneducated woman who began to take on extreme political beliefs. It was translated into many languages, many movies are also inspired by it.

The play The Mother by German playwright Bertolt Brecht is based on this novel.

[[Demaratus]]

CATEGORIES: 5th century BC deaths, Ancient Greeks, Kings of Sparta

Demaratus (Δημάρατος) was a co-king of Sparta from 515 until 491 BC. He succeeded his father Ariston as king. In 491 Demaratus and his co-king Cleomenes I became bitter rivals. Cleomenes plotted to have his kinsman Leotychides replace Demaratus as king. Cleomenes bribed the Oracle of Delphi to say that Demaratus was not actually the son of Ariston. Demaratus lost his kingship. But he still held a position as a magistrate in Sparta. After being ridiculed by the king over no longer being a king himself, Demaratus went into exile. He went to Darius I of Persia who gave him cities to rule over. Demaratus later went with king Xerxes I on his invasion of Greece in 480 BC. He warned Xerxes not to underestimate the Spartans before the Battle of Thermopylae.

[[These Boots Are Made for Walkin']]

CATEGORIES: 1966 songs

"These Boots Are Made For Walkin'“ is a song sung by Nancy Sinatra. It was released in early 1966.

The Mini Pop Kids sang it on their 2005 album, Mini Pop Kids 2.

Gemmy made 2 items that sang this song: go-go boots and a female turtle.December 2014

[[Analog television]]

CATEGORIES: Television

Analog television is broadcasting television programming using analog signals. Before digital television, all broadcasters used analog signals.

Analog television can be wireless or can be over a cable television network.

Many countries have changed from analog to digital television. Others are in the process of changing, and some have not started changing. 

The current deadline for "low power" TV stations in the United States to switch to digital television is July 13th 2021, over 60 years after analog was first made. The full power stations already switched in the months between February 12th and July 12th 2009. 

[[Simon Says]]

CATEGORIES: Games

The game of Simon Says is a childrens game. It is played in many parts of the world. 

[[Digital television]]

CATEGORIES: Television

Digital television is television broadcasting using digital signals. With digital television, more than one program can be sent at a time in the same channel bandwidth. It also provides a cleaner looking picture than analog.

Digital television has replaced analog television in many countries. These countries include Australia, Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States.

[[Fred Catherwood]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2014 deaths, Alumni of the University of Cambridge, British writers, Former MEPs, MEPs for the United Kingdom, Northern Ireland politicians

Sir Henry Frederick Ross Catherwood (31 January 1925 – 30 November 2014) was a British politician and writer.

Catherwood was born at Castledawson, County Londonderry, Northern Ireland. He was educated at Shrewsbury School and Clare College, Cambridge.

He was former Director General of the National Economic Development Council, and president of the Evangelical Alliance.

He was elected as a Conservative member of the European Parliament for Cambridgeshire and related areas from 1979 until his retirement in 1994.  He was Vice President of the European Parliament 1989-1992.

He married Elizabeth, the daughter of Christian pastor and author Martyn Lloyd-Jones. Their son Christopher Catherwood is an author. Fred Catherwood died in Cambridge, England on 30 November 2014 at the age of 89.

[[Martin Litton]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2014 deaths, American environmentalists, Sportspeople from California

Martin Litton (February 13, 1917 – November 30, 2014) was an American environmental activist and editor. He was a Grand Canyon river runner. Litton was best known as a staunch opponent of the construction of Glen Canyon Dam and other dams on the Colorado River.

On November 30, 2014, Litton died at his home in Palo Alto, California, aged 97.

[[Jarbom Gamlin]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from thrombosis, Indian politicians, Civil servants

Jarbom Gamlin (16 April 1961 – 30 November 2014) was an Indian politician. He was the leader of the Indian National Congress political party in Arunachal Pradesh. He was the Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh serving from May 2011 through October 2011.

Gamlin died from liver thrombosis in Gurgaon, Assam, aged 53.

[[Sita Murt]]

Sita Murt (ˈsitə ˈmurt; 1946 – 1 December 2014) was a Catalan fashion designer and businesswoman. She was born in Barcelona, Spain. She was known for designing soft clothing and for producing the clothes in the movie Vicky Christina Barcelona.

Murt died from cancer in Barcelona, Spain, aged 68.

[[Mary Beth Hughes]]

CATEGORIES: American television actors, American stage actors, American movie actors, Actors from Illinois, 1919 births, 1995 deaths

Mary Beth Hughes (November 13, 1919 – August 27, 1995) was an American stage, movie and television actress. She played Henry Fonda's former girlfriend in The Ox-Bow Incident (1943). She also played Sylvia in The Great Profile.

[[Stellinha Egg]]

[[Adriana Caselotti]]

Adriana Caselotti (May 6, 1916 – January 18, 1997) was an American voice actress and a singer. She voiced Snow White in Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs in 1937.

Caselotti was born in Bridgeport, Connecticut. She died in Los Angeles, California of respiratory failure from lung cancer.

[[Dorothy Morris]]

CATEGORIES: American television actors, American movie actors, Actors from Hollywood, 1922 births, 2011 deaths

Dorothy Morris (February 23, 1922 – November 20, 2011) was an American actress. She played roles of "the girl next door". She played Sue in Cry Havoc. She played Edith Bryant in This Time for Keeps.

Morris was born in Los Angeles, California. She died at age eighty-nine in Palm Springs, California

[[Denise Darcel]]

CATEGORIES: French television actors, French stage actors, French movie actors, 1924 births, 2011 deaths, Actors from Paris

Denise Darcel (born Denise Billecard; 8 September 1924 – 23 December 2011) was a French actress. She made movies in Hollywood. She played Gigi Mignon in Dangerous When Wet. She played Countess Marie in the movie Vera Cruz.

Darcel was born in Paris, France. She died at age 87 in Los Angeles, California from emergency surgery to repair a torn aneurysm.

[[Romford railway station]]

CATEGORIES: London Borough of Havering, Railway stations in London

Romford Railway Station is a major interchange station in Romford, Havering in Greater London. The station is located on the Great Eastern Main Line. Services that call at the station are operated by Abellio Greater Anglia, London Overground and TfL Rail. Services that stop at Romford are the Liverpool Street-Shenfield 'metro' services (TfL Rail) and Romford-Upminster services (London Overground). There are also long distance Abellio Greater Anglia services that stop at Romford. Crossrail is due to call at Romford in 2018. It will replace the current Liverpool Street-Shenfield service.

[[Tay Bridge disaster]]

CATEGORIES: 1879, 1870s in the United Kingdom, Bridges in the United Kingdom, 19th century in Scotland, Transport disasters in Europe

The Tay Bridge disaster was one of the great engineering disasters of the 19th century. It happened during a violent storm on 28 December 1879. The first Tay Rail Bridge collapsed while a train was passing over it from Wormit to Dundee, killing all aboard.

[[Clacton-on-sea railway station]]

CATEGORIES: Railway stations in England, Tendring, 1860 establishments in England

Clacton-on-Sea railway station is a railway station in England. It serves the town of Clacton-on-Sea in Essex. The station is near the town centre. It is in walking distance from the pier and sea. The station is on the Sunshine Coast Line. Services run to/from Colchester and Liverpool Street.

[[Yonne (river)]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of France, Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, Île-de-France

The Yonne is a river in the northern half of France. It flows mainly through the western part of the Bourgogne-Franche-Comté region, giving its name to the Yonne department and to several communes. It is the main left tributary of the Seine river.

The river was named during the Roman Empire as Icauna, a Latin word that likely came from the Celtic name for the river.

[[Barbara Kent]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from Alberta, American centenarians, American movie actors, 1907 births, 2011 deaths

Barbara Cloutman (later Barbara Kent; December 16, 1907 – October 13, 2011) was a Canadian-born and American-based actress of the 1920s and 1930s. She played Lotus in Chinatown after Dark. She played Amelia in the movie Vanity Fair (1932).

Kent was born in Alberta, Canada. She died at 103 in Palm Desert, California.

[[Chiltern Hills]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of England

The Chiltern Hills are chalk hills in southern England. They go 70 mi (115 km) southwest to northeast through parts of Oxfordshire, Buckinghamshire, Hertfordshire, and Bedfordshire. This makes a well-marked escarpment to the northwest and a gentle southeast slope to the River Thames. 

Considerable areas are now under the National Trust and are popular tourist attractions. The greatest elevation is Coombe Hill (852 ft m) near Wendover. The dense beechwoods still cover the western portions. They were once the basis of the traditional furniture industry of High Wycombe. Several passes through the Chiltern Hills are used by roads and railways to London.

[[Horacio Cartes]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, People from Asunción, Presidents of Paraguay

Horacio Manuel Cartes Jara (born 5 July 1956) is an Paraguayan politician. He served as President of Paraguay from 2013 through 2018.

Cartes won the 2013 presidential election in Paraguay on 21 April 2013 and took office as President on 15 August 2013.

Horacio Cartes is the owner of "Grupo Cartes", a conglomerate of approximately two dozen of companies. He has also been president of the football club Club Libertad since 2001 

[[Hammond organ]]

CATEGORIES: Keyboard instruments

The Hammond organ is a keyboard instrument that looks like a piano. The most common Hammond organs create sound using metal wheels and electricity. It is an electric version of a pipe organ that was invented by Laurens Hammond and John M. Hanert. It was first built in 1935. Sliding "drawbars" adjust the type of sound that the organ makes. The Hammond organ is one of the most successful organs made because almost two million Hammond organs were sold.

[[Mario Abramovich]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2014 deaths, Argentine Jews, Argentine musicians, Composers, Jewish musicians, Violinists

Mario Abramovich (31 October 1926 – 1 December 2014) was an Argentine violinist and composer of Jewish descent. He was a member of the group Sexteto Mayor since its founding in 1973, until his death in 2014. He was known for performing in the Argentine album Bête Noire.

Abramovich died in Buenos Aires, Argentina, aged 88.

[[Bobby Keys]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2014 deaths, American saxophonists, Cancer deaths in Tennessee, Deaths from liver failure, Musicians from Texas

Robert Henry "Bobby" Keys (December 18, 1943 – December 2, 2014) was an American saxophone player. He performed with other musicians as a member of several horn sections of the 1970s. He appears on albums by The Rolling Stones, Lynyrd Skynyrd, The Who, Harry Nilsson, Delaney Bramlett, George Harrison, Eric Clapton and Joe Cocker, amongst other notable musicians. Keys was a touring musician from 1956 until his death in 2014. Keys was born in Slaton, Texas.

Keys had cancer and liver failure. He died at his home in Franklin, Tennessee on December 2, 2014, aged 70.

[[Twist Bread]]

CATEGORIES: Breads

Twist bread is a type of bread rolled into a long sausage shape and twisted over a stick.  It is then baked over an open fire.

The dough is made like ordinary bread dough with yeast as a leavening agent.

[[CamelCase]]

CATEGORIES: Typography

CamelCase (camel case, camel caps or medial capitals) is the practice of writing compound words or phrases so that each next word or abbreviation begins with a capital letter. CamelCase can either start with a lowercase or uppercase letter, although the lowerCase version is much more common in programming. Common examples are PowerPoint or iPhone.

[[Ibrahim Lodi]]

CATEGORIES: Sultans, Indian people

Ibrahim Lodi (d. 21 April 1526) was the last sultan of Delhi. He was an ethnic Pashtun. He became sultan in 1517 after Sikandar Lodi died. Sikandar was his father and Ibrahim was soon challenged by his younger brother, Jalal Kahn. Ibrahim had military skills. But unlike his father he lacked tact. 

He faced a number of rebellions. The Mewar ruler Rana Sangram Singh extended his empire right up to western Uttar Pradesh and threatened to attack Agra. There was rebellion in the East also. Ibrahim Lodi also displeased the nobility when he replaced old and senior commanders by younger ones who were loyal to him. He further alienated them by throwing some of the older noblemen in prison. His Afghan nobility eventually invited Babur to invade India. In 1526, the Mughal forces of Babur, the king of Kabulistan, defeated Ibrahim's much larger army in the 1st Battle of Panipat. Ibrahim was killed during the battle. It is estimated that Babur's forces numbered around 12,000 men. His army had between 20 to 24 pieces of field artillery. Ibrahim Lodi had around 30,000-40,000 men along with at least 100 war elephants. After Ibrahim Lodi was overthrown, the mughals invaded India.

[[St Nicholas Day]]

CATEGORIES: Christian holidays

Saint Nicholas Day is the feast day of Saint Nicholas. It is on December 6 (December 19 in most Orthodox countries).  It is a festival for children in many countries around Europe related to surviving legends of Saint Nicholas.  The American Santa Claus, as well as the British Father Christmas, are based on these legends. "Santa Claus" is based in part from the Dutch Sinterklaas.

Saint Nicholas in different countries travels with different people. He may travel with Angels, Krampus, and others.

[[Julio Velasco]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people, Argentine sportspeople, Volleyball coaches

Julio Velasco (born February 9, 1952 in La Plata, Argentina) is a professional volleyball coach from Argentina. He guided the Italian national men's team to several successes in the 1990s. After the 1996 Summer Olympics, where the Italians won silver, he switched to the Italian women's team (1996–1997). In 2011, Velasco was signed as the head coach of the Iran men's national team. He became coach of the Argentina men's national team before his contract expired with the Iranian national team on 1 March 2014. The President of Argentina asked him to take this job. The change was approved by the Iranian volleyball confederation.

[[Marina Oswald Porter]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people

Marina Nikolayevna Oswald Porter (July 17, 1941) is the widow of Lee Harvey Oswald. According to the Warren Commission he was the sole assassin of U.S. President John F. Kennedy.

[[Alisohbat Sumbatzade]]

CATEGORIES: Azerbaijani historians, Azerbaijani writers, People from Baku, 1907 births, 1992 deaths

Alisohbat Sumbat oglu Sumbatzade (8 January 1907, Amirjan, Baku – 1992, Baku) was an Azerbaijani historian and orientalist (and a member of the Academy of Sciences of the Azerbaijani SSR from 1958).

Sumbatzade graduated from the Department of Oriental Studies of Azerbaijan State University in 1929. In 1963 he became director of the Institute of the Peoples of the Near and Middle East of the Academy of Sciences of the Azerbaijan SSR. Sumbatzade's main works are on the socioeconomic history of Azerbaijan in the 19th and 20th centuries.

[[Aydin Balayev]]

CATEGORIES: Azerbaijani historians, Azerbaijani writers, 1956 births, Living people, People from Baku

Aydin Balayev Huseynaga oglu (Aydın Balayev Hüseynağa oğlu; born November 19, 1956) is an Azerbaijani historian, ethnologist and professor.

[[Don Laws]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, American figure skaters, Sportspeople from Washington, D.C.

Don Laws (May 30, 1929 – December 2, 2014) was an American figure skater and coach. Laws competed in single skating and ice dancing. With his ice dancing partner, Mary Firth, he won the U.S. junior title in 1948. Laws was born in Washington, D. C..

In men's singles, he won the 1950 U.S. junior title and placed seventh at the 1951 World Championships in Milan, Italy. He was coached by Osborne Colson.

Laws died of heart failure in Sandy Springs, Maryland, aged 85.

[[Jean Béliveau]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2014 deaths, Canadian ice hockey centres, Conn Smythe Trophy winners, Hart Memorial Trophy winners, Hockey Hall of Fame inductees, Ice hockey people from Quebec, Montreal Canadiens players, Sportspeople from Quebec, Stanley Cup champions

Joseph Jean Arthur Béliveau, (August 31, 1931 – December 2, 2014) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player. He played parts of 20 seasons with the National Hockey League's (NHL) Montreal Canadiens from 1950 to 1971. He was nicknamed "Le Gros Bill". 

Béliveau ranks among the ten greatest NHL players. Béliveau first played professionally in the Quebec Major Hockey League (QMHL). He made his NHL debut with the Canadiens in 1950, but chose to remain in the QMHL full-time until 1953.

Béliveau was born in Trois-Rivières, Quebec, Canada. 

By his second season in the NHL, Béliveau was among the top three scorers. He was the fourth player to score 500 goals and the second to score 1,000 points. Béliveau won two Hart Memorial Trophies (1956, 1964) and one Art Ross Memorial Trophy (1956), as well as the inaugural Conn Smythe Trophy (1965). 

As a player, he won the Stanley Cup 10 times, and as an executive he was part of another seven championship teams, the most Stanley Cup victories by an individual to date. He was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1972.

Béliveau died on December 2, 2014 at the age of 83, in Longueuil, Quebec, Canada, a suburb of Montreal from unknown causes.

[[Luc Oursel]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2014 deaths, French businesspeople

Luc Oursel, (7 September 1959 – 3 December 2014), was a French businessman. He was the former chairman of the board of the nuclear company Areva and member of its Executive Committee.

He resigned on October 20, 2014 for health reasons. Until June 2013, he was the President of the French Nuclear Energy Corporation.

[[Lynne Kosky]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from breast cancer, Civil servants, Politicians from Melbourne

Lynne Janice Kosky (2 September 1958 – 4 December 2014) was a former Australian politician and senior minister in the Parliament of Victoria.  She represented the electoral district of Altona in the Victorian Legislative Assembly for the Australian Labor Party from 1996 to 2010

Kosky died from breast cancer in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, aged 56.

[[Jacques Barrot]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2014 deaths, European Commissioners, French mayors, Government ministers of France, People from Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes

Jacques Barrot (February 3, 1937 – December 3, 2014) was a French politician. He served as European Commissioner for Justice between 2008 and 2010, after having spent four years serving as Commissioner for Transport (2004–2008) and Commissioner for Regional Policy for eight months (2004).

He was also a minister, and mayor of Yssingeaux.

[[Ian McLagan]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2014 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Texas, Deaths from stroke, English songwriters, Musicians from Middlesex

Ian Patrick 'Mac' McLagan ˈ; (12 May 1945 – 3 December 2014) was an English keyboard instrumentalist. He was best known as a member of the English Rock bands Small Faces and Faces. He also worked with The Rolling Stones and led his own band from the late 1970s.

McLagan died on 3 December 2014, reportedly due to a massive stroke, in Austin, Texas aged 69.

[[Herman Badillo]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, Puerto Rican people, United States representatives from New York, Bronx borough presidents, US Democratic Party politicians

Herman Badillo (August 21, 1929 – December 3, 2014) was an American politician. He was a borough president, United States Representative and candidate for Mayor of New York City. He was the first Puerto Rican to have been elected to these posts and been a mayoral candidate in the continental United States.

Badillo died on December 3, 2014 of congestive heart failure in Manhattan, New York, aged 85.

Reyno died from respiratory failure in Montevideo, Uruguay, aged 79.

[[Ed Wynn]]

CATEGORIES: 1886 births, 1966 deaths, Deaths from throat cancer, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American radio actors, Actors from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Comedians from Pennsylvania

Ed Wynn (November 9, 1886 – June 19, 1966) was a popular American comedian and actor. He was known for his role as the Mad Hatter in the 1951 animated movie Alice in Wonderland. His son, Keenan Wynn, was also an actor.

Wynn died of throat cancer in Beverly Hills, California, aged 79.

[[Red Skelton]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 1997 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, American television personalities, American radio personalities, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, American radio actors, Actors from Indiana, Comedians from Indiana

Richard Bernard Eheart professionally known as Red Skelton (July 18, 1913 – September 17, 1997) was an American entertainer. He was best known for his national radio and television acts between 1937 and 1971 and as host of the television program The Red Skelton Show.

Skelton died in Rancho Mirage, California from pneumonia, aged 84.

[[The Mechanic (1972 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies directed by Michael Winner

The Mechanic is a 1972 American thriller movie directed by Michael Winner. It stars Charles Bronson, Jan-Michael Vincent, Keenan Wynn, Frank de Kova, Celeste Yarnall and Jill Ireland. It was released to mostly positive reviews on November 17, 1972.

[[Keenan Wynn]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 1986 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Keenan Wynn (July 27, 1916 – October 14, 1986) was an American character actor. He was born in New York City, New York. He was known for his role in the 1972 thriller movie The Mechanic.

Wynn died of pancreatic cancer in Los Angeles, California, aged 70.

[[Frank de Kova]]

CATEGORIES: 1910 births, 1981 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Frank de Kova (March 17, 1910 – October 15, 1981) was an Italian-American character actor. de Kova was born in New York City. He was known for his role as "The Man" in the 1972 thriller movie The Mechanic.

de Kova died of heart failure at his home in Sepulveda, California, aged 71.

[[Realpolitik]]

CATEGORIES: Politics

Realpolitik is a system of politics or principles based on practical, rather than moral or ideological considerations. Realpolitik is the idea that the world is ruthless and you have to act realistically, even if it causes other things to happen that are bad, or decisions have to be made that upset your people.

Ludwig von Rochau was a 19th century writer and politician. He describes it as follows: The study of the powers that shape, maintain and alter the state is the basis of all political insight and leads to the understanding that the law of power governs the world of states just as the law of gravity governs the physical world.

A good example of a realpolitik politician is Henry Kissinger, who helped U.S. Presidents in the 1960s and 1970s to expand the power of the United States and its allies.

[[Linda Christian]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2011 deaths, Actresses who played Bond girls, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors

Linda Christian (November 13, 1923 – July 22, 2011) was a Mexican actress. She appeared in Mexican and Hollywood movies. She worked mostly in the 1940s and 1950s. She was the first Bond girl, appearing in the 1954 movie Casino Royale.

Christian was born Blanca Rose Welter in Tampico, Mexico. She died in Palm Desert, California at age eighty-seven.

[[Regression toward the mean]]

CATEGORIES: Statistics

Regression toward the mean simply means that, following an extreme random event, the next random event is likely to be less extreme. Regression toward the mean was first described by Francis Galton. He found that offspring of tall parents tended to be shorter. Also, offspring of shorter parents tended to be taller. Galton stated that processes that did not follow regression towards the mean would quickly go out of control.

[[Promised Land (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Gus Van Sant

Promised Land is a 2012 drama movie. It was directed by Gus Van Sant. It stars Matt Damon, John Krasinski, Frances McDormand, Hal Holbrook and Rosemarie DeWitt. The screenplay is written by Damon and Krasinski based on a story by Dave Eggers. The movie is about two corporate salespeople. They visit a rural town trying to buy drilling rights from local residents. This movie had a limited release in the United States on December 28, 2012. It was released nationwide on January 4, 2013.

[[Comrade]]

CATEGORIES: Politics

Comrade is the name given to someone who belongs to the same social group, party or company. It literally means friend, colleague, but it also means ally. The term can refer to someone who has the same beliefs or values. That way, in Communism, people who belong to the Communist Party address each other as comrade. 

Terms like this avoid using titles, rank or any other sign that one person is better than, or different from, another. 

[[Giulio Questi]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2014 deaths, Italian movie directors, Italian screenwriters, People from Lombardy

Giulio Questi (18 March 1924 – 3 December 2014) was an Italian movie director and screenwriter. He was known for his roles in La morte ha fatto l'uovo and Django Kill! (If You Live Shoot!). Questi was born in Bergamo, Lombardy, Italy.

Questi died in Rome, Italy, aged 90.

[[Sjefke Janssen]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2014 deaths, Dutch cyclists, Sportspeople from Limburg (Netherlands)

Sjefke Janssen (October 28, 1919 – December 3, 2014) was a Dutch professional road bicycle racer. He was known for his bronze medal in the Elite race of the 1947 UCI Road World Championships.

Janssen was a professional cyclist from 1946 through 1954. After retiring, he became a cycling team-manager and owned a bicycle shop in Elsloo.

He was born and died in Elsloo. At the time of his death, Janssen was the oldest living Dutch Tour de France racer.

He was the father of Dutch Olympic team dressage coach Sjef Janssen.

[[V. R. Krishna Iyer]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2014 deaths, Autobiographers, Cardiovascular disease deaths in India, Centenarians, Civil servants, Deaths from heart failure, Deaths from renal failure, Indian politicians, Indian writers, Indian judges

Vaidyanathapura Rama Krishna Iyer (15 November 1914 – 4 December 2014), popularly known as V. R. Krishna Iyer, was an Indian judge in the Supreme Court of India. He was born at Vaidyanathapuram near Palakkad, in Malabar region of Kerala. He served in the Supreme Court from 1973 until his death in 2014.

Iyer died in Kochi, Kerala, India from renal and heart failure, aged 100.

[[Claudia Emerson]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, American poets, Writers from Virginia

Claudia Emerson (January 13, 1957 – December 4, 2014) was an American poet. She won the 2006 Pulitzer Prize for her poetry collection Late Wife. She was named the Poet Laureate of Virginia by Governor Tim Kaine in 2008. Emerson was born in Chatham, Virginia.

Emerson died in Richmond, Virginia from colon cancer, aged 57.

[[Gershon Kingsley]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2019 deaths, 20th century composers, 21st century composers, American composers, Naturalized citizens of the United States, People from Bochum

Gershon Kingsley (born Götz Gustav Ksinski; October 28, 1922 – December 10, 2019) was a German-American composer. His music genre included electronic music and the Moog synthesizer. He was the founder of the First Moog Quartet, as a partner in the electronic music duo Perrey and Kingsley, and writer of rock-inspired compositions for Jewish religious ceremonies.

Because of his Jewish background (his father was Jewish),  he moved to Mandatory Palestine in 1938. After the war he moved to the United States.

Kingsley died on December 10, 2019 at the age of 97.

[[Death Wish (1974 movie)]]

Death Wish is a 1974 American crime-action movie directed by Michael Winner. It is based on the book Death Wish. It stars Charles Bronson. It was released on July 24, 1974 to positive reviews. It is the first movie in the Death Wish movie series. A remake was released in March 2018.

[[The Barry Sisters]]

CATEGORIES: Musical groups from New York, American jazz singers, People from the Bronx

Minnie (1923 – October 31, 1976) and Clara Bagelman (October 17, 1920 – November 22, 2014), also known as by the stage names Merna and Claire Barry, or The Barry Sisters, were popular American jazz entertainers. They worked from the 1940s to the 1970s. 

Minnie and Clara were born in Bronx, New York. Merna Barry died from a brain tumor, age 54. Clara died at age 94.

[[Pleurisy]]

CATEGORIES: Infectious diseases, Pulmonology

Pleurisy (also known as pleuritis) is an inflammation of the pleura, the lining surrounding the lungs. There are many possible causes of pleurisy but viral infections spreading from the lungs to pleural cavity are the most common. Pleurisy can cause sharp pain when breathing, also called pleuritic chest pain. 

[[Rita Reys]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2013 deaths, Dutch musicians, Jazz musicians, Jazz singers, People from Rotterdam

Rita Reys (21 December 1924 – 28 July 2013) was a jazz singer from the Netherlands. In 1960, she was given the title "Europe's first lady of jazz". She sang jazz and bossa nova.

Reys was born in Rotterdam. She died in Breukelen at age eighty-eight.

[[Regina Resnik]]

Regina Resnik (August 30, 1922 – August 8, 2013) was an American mezzo-soprano opera singer. She sang on many stages in the United States. She was known for performing in Il trovatore, La Gioconda, and in Aida.

She was born in The Bronx, New York. She died at age ninety.

[[David Steel]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Former Liberal Democrats MPs (UK), Former members of the British House of Commons for Scottish constituencies, Leaders of the Liberal Democrats (UK), Leaders of the Liberal Party (UK), Liberal Party MPs (UK), Members of the House of Lords, Privy Councillors (UK), Scottish Parliament Members, UK MPs 1964–1966, UK MPs 1966–1970, UK MPs 1970–1974, UK MPs 1974, UK MPs 1974–1979, UK MPs 1979–1983, UK MPs 1983–1987, UK MPs 1987–1992, UK MPs 1992–1997

David Martin Scott Steel, Baron Steel of Aikwood (born 31 March 1938) is a British retired Liberal politician. 

Steel served as the Leader of the Liberal Party from 1976 until its merger with the Social Democratic Party in 1988 to form the Liberal Democrats. He served as a Member of Parliament (MP) from 1965 to 1997 and as a Member of the Scottish Parliament (MSP) from 1999 to 2003.

[[Mathieu Kérékou]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2015 deaths, Presidents of Benin

Mathieu Kérékou, (2 September 1933 – 14 October 2015) was a Beninese politician. He was President of Benin from 1972 to 1991 and again from 1996 to 2006.

After seizing power in a military coup, he ruled the country for 17 years. He was defeated in the 1991 presidential election, but was returned to the presidency in the 1996 election and controversially re-elected in 2001.

[[Hull Fair]]

CATEGORIES: Events in the United Kingdom

Hull Fair is one of Europe's largest traveling fairs. In 1993 the fair celebrated its 700th anniversary.

It comes to Hull, England for one week. The fair opens on the Friday closest to 11 October each year. During this time the fair is open every day except Sunday. Unlike small local fairs, Hull Fair attracts rides, attractions and travellers from a wide variety of different regions from around the country. the fair is opened by the Lord Mayor of Hull on the opening evening, normally at 5 pm. It first opened from 9 to 23 March 1278.

In 1752 when the calendar changed in Great Britain, 11 days were lost. Wednesday, 2 September 1752 was followed by Thursday, 14 September 1752. The people of Hull believed this took away their fair. Angry mobs shouted “Give us back our eleven days”. The outraged citizens were given their wish. Even since then, October 11th, or the Friday closest to it, became the fair's starting date.

[[Escape (album)]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 albums

Escape is the seventh studio album by the American rock band Journey. The album was released on July 31, 1981. It was the group's fourth studio album with vocalist Steve Perry. 

[[Khalifa bin Hamad Al Thani]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2016 deaths, Prime Ministers of Qatar

Emir Sheikh Khalifa bin Hamad bin Abdullah bin Jassim bin Muhammed Al Thani GCB GCMG (17 September 1932 – 23 October 2016; Arabic خليفة بن حمد آل ثاني) was the Emir of Qatar from 27 February 1972 until he was deposed by his son Hamad bin Khalifa on 27 June 1995.

Khalifa died at the age of 84 on 23 October 2016 in Doha, Qatar after being hospitalized for a week.

[[Jackie Healy-Rae]]

Healy-Rae was born in County Kerry, Irish Free State. He died on 5 December 2014 at Kerry General Hospital in Tralee, County Kerry after a long illness, aged 83.

[[Manuel De Sica]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2014 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Italy, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Italian composers, Musicians from Rome

Manuel De Sica (24 February 1949 – 5 December 2014) was an Italian composer. He was born in Rome, Italy. In 1993, De Sica won the Nastro d'Argento for Best Score for Carlo Verdone's Al lupo, al lupo. In 1996 he won the David di Donatello for Best Score for Carlo Lizzani's Celluloide. In 2005 he was honored with the title of Commendatore of the Italian Republic.

Sica died of a heart attack in Rome on 5 December 2014, aged 65.

[[Queen Fabiola of Belgium]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2014 deaths, Kings and Queens of Belgium, Kings and Queens consort, People from Madrid

Queen Fabiola of Belgium (born Doña Fabiola de Mora y Aragón; 11 June 1928 – 5 December 2014) was the widow of King Baudouin. She was queen consort for 33 years, between her wedding in 1960 and her husband's death in 1993. The couple did not have children. When he died, the crown passed to her his younger brother, King Albert II.

On 5 December 2014, the Belgian Royal Palace announced Queen Fabiola had died that evening at Stuyvenbergh Castle in Laeken, Belgium, aged 86.

[[Republic of Molossia]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 establishments in the United States, Geography of California, Geography of Nevada

Molossia, also known as the self-proclaimed Republic of Molossia, is a micronation, founded by Kevin Baugh and headquartered in his home near Dayton, Nevada. Baugh has also been the president since 3 September 1999. 

Before holding this office Baugh was prime minister of Vuldstein, Edelstein, and Zaria from 1977 to 1999. He changed Molossia from a monarchy to a republic.

Molossia is made up of Baugh's house (known as the Government House), about 0.001 in size, as well as 1.3 of surrounding property, enclaved by Nevada. It formerly claimed a property in Pennsylvania as well. According to author John Ryan, Molossia is "a hobby that has been pushed to the nth degree."  Originally established as a childhood project in 1977, Molossia subsequently evolved into a territorial entity in the late 1990s.

The name Molossia is derived from the Spanish word morro which means "small rocky hill".  Baugh has stated that the ancient Greek tribe of Molossians is unrelated.

[[Kevin Baugh]]

CATEGORIES: Royal Order of Saint Christopher, Molossia, 1962 births, Living people

Kevin Baugh, (born 1962) is a Molossian politician and popular micronationalist. Baugh has been serving as President of the Republic of Molossia since 3 September 1999. His Presidential term started on the 3 September 1999, which is the official date of foundation of Molossia. However, his involvement in micronationalism goes way back to the end of the 1970s, when he formed, with James Spielman, the Grand Republic of Vuldstein.

[[Gay and Lesbian Kingdom of the Coral Sea Islands]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 establishments in Australia, Geography of Queensland, LGBT

The Gay and Lesbian Kingdom of the Coral Sea Islands was a micronation created as a symbolic political protest by a group of gay rights activists based in southeast Queensland, Australia.  Declared in 2004 in response to the Australian government's refusal to recognise same-sex marriages. It is near the islets on the Great Barrier Reef.  It is an expression of queer nationalism.

As of 17 November 2017, the Kingdom was dissolved, per the decision made by the Australian people to legalize gay marriage.

[[Dick Wilson]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2007 deaths, Actors from Lancashire, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, English movie actors, English television actors

Dick Wilson, born Riccardo Di Guglielmo (30 July 1916 – 19 November 2007), was a British-Canadian character actor. He was known for playing grocery store manager Mr. (George) Whipple in over 500 Charmin toilet paper television commercials (1965–1989, 1999-2000).

Wilson was raised in Hamilton, Ontario. He died in Woodland Hills, Los Angeles, California, aged 91.

[[Pedro Lascuráin]]

CATEGORIES: 1856 births, 1952 deaths, Presidents of Mexico, Mayors, Politicians from Mexico City

Pedro José Domingo de la Calzada Manuel María Lascuráin Paredes (8 May  1856 – 21 July 1952) was a Mexican politician.

He served as the 38th President of Mexico. He served as president for less than one hour on February 19, 1913. It is the shortest presidency in the history of the world. He had earlier served as Mexico's foreign minister for two terms and was the director of a small law school in Mexico City for sixteen years.

[[Alma Cogan]]

Alma Cogan (19 May 1932 – 26 October 1966) was an English singer of traditional pop in the 1950s and early 1960s. She was called "the girl with the giggle in her voice". One of her hit songs was "Sugartime". It was released in 1958 alongside The McGuire Sisters' version.

[[Typhoon Hagupit (2014)]]

CATEGORIES: Tropical cyclones in Asia, 2014 in weather, 2014 in Asia

Typhoon Hagupit (called Typhoon Ruby in the Philippines) was a strong tropical cyclone in the western Pacific Ocean. The storm headed towards the Philippines.

Storm warnings and notices were up for the Philippines because of this typhoon.

Hagupit became a tropical storm on December 1, 2014. It became a typhoon the next day.

[[.NET Framework]]

CATEGORIES: Microsoft software

.NET Framework (pronounced dot net) is a product of Microsoft. It is a programming framework used by Software applications in order to run. It has two major parts: the Common Language Runtime (CLR) and the .Net Framework Class Library. The CLR is an execution engine used to handle running programs. The class library provides a library of reusable code that applications can use. These are designed to greatly simplify the development of larger applications. .Net Framework supports Object-oriented programming (OOP). Everything in .Net is contained in an object. It also greatly simplifies Windows programming.

Often, a program will ask for a particular version of .Net Framework to be installed (see below). It is usually recommended to install the latest version your operating system (OS) will support. This is because of backward compatibility; the newer version will also support older versions. 

Visual Studio is the major development tool for .net Framework. Visual Studio 2013 Community Edition is the first full-featured edition for personal development. It also has compilers for computer programming languages such as C++ and others. 

[[Physical Address Extension]]

CATEGORIES: Computer science

In computing, Physical Address Extension (PAE) is a processor feature to enable 32-bit IA-32 central processing units (CPUs) to access physical address space larger than 4 gigabytes by extending the paging schema . It allows up to 64 gigabytes of system memory to be addressed by a 32-bit processor. 

PAE was first introduced with the Intel 32-bit processor Pentium Pro. Since then it has been a feature on all Intel processors except some Pentium M mobile processors. Athlon or K7 is the first processor from AMD supported PAE. Now all AMD processors support PAE. In addition to processor support, PAE requires the operating system (OS) to support it. Windows 2000 was the first OS to support PAE.

[[Nested Paging]]

CATEGORIES: Computer science

In Computer Platform Virtulisatin, Nested Paging is used to unburden the Hypervisor from heavy work with Guest OS memory translation. Before, Hypervisor needs to employ a second page table keeping track of guest page table, and force the guest OS use it to access system physical memory. For doing this, Hypervisor needs to monitor the paging activities of guest OS and intercept it with necessarily inserting, deleting or modifying entries in this second page table. This consumes processor's time and system physical memory space. Nested Paging provides a Second Level Address Translation. With help of it, Hypervisor does not need to maintain that second page table with intercepting activities on guest paging. It simply maintains the nested page table for translating the guest physical address into the system physical address. After nested page table created, the paging hardware does the translation job automatically. Each guest physical access would incur nested paging, for a 48-bit address paging in 4KiB, a guest physical address translation would need 25 accesses of system physical memory. So larger TLB and page size would decrease the system physical memory accesses.  

[[Jasper County (album)]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 albums

Jasper County is the ninth studio album by Trisha Yearwood. The album was released on September 13, 2005. It was her first studio album in 4 years. The album was also the return of producer Garth Fundis who produced her Greatest hits album. It was ninth and final studio album of label MCA Nashville Records.

Land transport or Land transportation is the movement of people, animals, and goods from one location to another on land.  Today this is usually by rail or road transport. 

[[Lisa Ajax]]

Her recording of the song "Love Run Free" has reached the 48th position at Itunes during its first week at chart. 

On 5 December 2014, she won the Idol finals inside the Stockholm Globe Arena before runner up Mollie Lindén.

She also participated at Lilla Melodifestivalen 2012 with the song "Allt som jag har".

[[Intercalation (timekeeping)]]

CATEGORIES: Calendars

Calendars are commonly based on the rotation of celestial bodies, such as the sun or the moon. These calendars periodically add a certain time unit, to make the calendar follow the rotation more closely, which is known as intercalation. As an example, the solar year is about 365,25 days long. The Gregorian calendar says that the year has 365 days, but that roughly every four years, an extra day is added. 

Another example is the Jewish calendar, which is a lunisolar calendar. In addition to the 365,25 days of the solar year, there are the 29.5 days in a lunar month. This gives the problem that the year does not have twelve months, but about 12.4 months. The calendar solves this problem by adding an extra month in certain cases.

List of Tekken Characters

[[Numbers station]]

CATEGORIES: Radio stations

A Numbers station is a kind of shortwave radio station with unusual broadcasts: very often, these broadcasts consist of numbers that are read by computer-generated voices. Several of these stations exist, numbers are read in different languages. Some stations have operated for a period of more than ten years, using the same frequency. 

The purpose of the stations is unknown, along with who operates them. One supposition is that governments use them to communicate with secret agents or spies. As receiving the messages is relatively simple, the agent only needs a world radio receiver.

[[Communications receiver]]

CATEGORIES: Radio receivers

A communications receiver is a radio receiver which is specially suited for receiving shortwave radio stations. Unlike other radio stations, shortwave stations are usually broadcast from one sender only. They can then be received all over the world. The upper class communications receivers are also able to receive differently modulated radio signals, such as single-sideband modulation. 

[[Loop antenna]]

CATEGORIES: Radio antennas

A loop antenna is a radio antenna consisting of at least one loop of wire, tubing, or other electrical conductor with its ends connected to a balanced transmission line. Within this physical description two different antenna designs are common: the small loop (or magnetic loop) with a size much smaller than a wavelength, and the resonant loop antenna with a circumference approximately equal to the wavelength.

Small loops have a poor efficiency and are mainly used as receiving antennas at low frequencies. Except for car radios, almost every AM broadcast receiver sold  has such an antenna built in or directly attached to it. These antennas are also used for radio direction finding.  In amateur radio, loop antennas can be used where larger antennas would be inconvenient, unsightly, or banned because of size. Loop antennas are relatively easy to build.

A small loop antenna, also known as a magnetic loop, generally has a circumference of less than one tenth of a wavelength, in which case there will be a relatively constant current distribution along the conductor.  As the frequency or the size is increased, a standing wave starts to develop in the current, and the antenna starts to acquire some of the characteristics of a resonant loop (but is not resonant); for this reason, these intermediate cases cannot be analyzed using the concepts developed for the small and resonant loop antennas described below. 

Resonant loop antennas are relatively large, governed by the intended wavelength of operation. Thus they are typically used at higher frequencies, especially VHF and UHF, where their size is manageable. They can be viewed as a folded dipole deformed into a different shape, and have rather similar characteristics such as a high radiation efficiency.

[[Wellfleet, Massachusetts]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Massachusetts

Wellfleet is a town in Barnstable County, Massachusetts, United States. It is located halfway between the "tip" and "elbow" of Cape Cod. The town had a population of 2,750 at the 2010 census. The population grows to over six times the normal during the summer. Much of the town's land area is in wetlands protection. Nearly half of it is part of the Cape Cod National Seashore. Wellfleet is famous for its oysters, which are celebrated in the annual October Wellfleet OysterFest.

[[Nils Börge Gårdh]]

Nils Börge Gårdh, born 20 February 1946 in Falun, Sweden is a Swedish Christian singer and businessman. His major solo hit was Jag längtar bort. It charted at the top 10-chart Svensktoppen for 10 weeks in 1982. He also works for the Hoppets stjärna charity organization.

[[Night of Champions (2012)]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 in professional wrestling, Sports in Boston, Massachusetts, WWE Night of Champions, 2012 in the United States, 2010s in Boston, Massachusetts

Night of Champions was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by WWE. It was held on September 16, 2012 at TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts. It was the fifth WWE Night of Champions event held by the WWE. 

The main event was a match between WWE Champion CM Punk and John Cena. The end of match saw Cena place Punk on the top rope and hit a bridging German suplex for the pin. The referee declared that both men had their shoulders on the mat for three seconds and ended the match in a draw.

[[Armageddon (1999)]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 in American television, 1999 in professional wrestling, Sports in Florida, WWE Armageddon, 1990s in Florida

Armageddon (1999) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Federation. It was held on December 12, 1999 at National Car Rental Center in Sunrise, Florida. It was the first Armageddon event held by the WWF.

The main event saw Triple H defeat Vince McMahon in a No Holds Barred match. Triple H won the match by pinning Vince after he hit McMahon with a sledgehammer, when Vince's daughter and Triple H's (kayfabe, at that time) wife Stephanie McMahon had turned on Vince by giving the sledgehammer to Triple H.

[[Armageddon (2000)]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 in American television, 2000 in professional wrestling, Birmingham, Alabama, WWE Armageddon, 20th century in Alabama

Armageddon (2000) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Federation (WWF). It was held on December 10, 2000 at Birmingham-Jefferson Civic Center in Birmingham, Alabama. It was the second Armageddon event held by the WWF. It was the only WWF pay-per-view event to be held in the state of Alabama.

The main event was a six-man Hell in a Cell for Kurt Angle's WWF Championship. Kurt Angle defeated Stone Cold Steve Austin, Triple H, The Undertaker, Rikishi, and The Rock to retain his championship.

[[Armageddon (2002)]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 in American television, 2002 in professional wrestling, Sports in Florida, WWE Armageddon, 2000s in Florida

Armageddon (2002) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). It was held on December 15, 2002 at Office Depot Center in Sunrise, Florida. It was the third Armageddon event held by the WWE.

The main match for the Raw brand saw Triple H defeat Shawn Michaels in a Three Stages of Hell match for the World Heavyweight Championship. The first match was a Street Fight, which Triple H won after performing a Pedigree on Michaels and pinning him. The second match was a Steel cage match, which Michaels was able to win by pinfall after he jumped off the top of the steel cage onto Triple H and through a table. The third and final match was a Ladder match, which Triple H won after he climbed up a ladder and grabbed the belt which was suspended above the ring.

The main event for SmackDown! saw Kurt Angle defeat The Big Show to retain his WWE Championship. Angle pinned Big Show after Brock Lesnar interfered. Another match that was on the undercard saw Chris Benoit defeat Eddie Guerrero in a submission match. Benoit made Guerrero tap out to the Crippler Crossface.

[[Phaedra (mythology)]]

CATEGORIES: People in Greek mythology

Phaedra is the daughter of Minos and Pasiphaë in Greek mythology. She is also the wife of Theseus, the sister of Ariadne and the mother of Demophon of Athens and of Acamas. Phaedra's name comes from a Greek word, which means "bright". 

There are many versions of the story of Phaedra. One is about murder and revenge.

[[Summer Wine]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 songs, 1960s ballads, Pop ballads, Songs about sexuality

"Summer Wine" is a seductive ballad. It was originally sung by Suzi Jane Hokom and Lee Hazlewood in 1966. It was made famous when released by Nancy Sinatra and Lee Hazlewood in 1967.

The song is about a man who meets a woman who notices his silver spurs. She invites him to have wine with her.

The song was recorded by other musicians since it was first played. 

[[Somethin' Stupid]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 songs, 1960s ballads, Pop songs, Pop ballads, Frank Sinatra songs

"Somethin' Stupid" is a ballad written by C. Carson Parks.

It was recorded in 1966 by Parks and his wife Gaile Foote. The song is best known for being recorded by Frank Sinatra and his daughter Nancy. The Sinatras' version became popular as it spent four weeks at the #1 spot on the Billboard Hot 100. 

The song was also recorded by Tammy Wynette, The Lennon Sisters, Marvin Gaye, Robbie Williams and Nicole Kidman and many others.

[[Oden]]

CATEGORIES: Japanese food

Oden (おでん, or 関東煮) is one of the Japanese stewing food. Oden contains a lot of ingredients in seasoned soup. Ingredients and soup are different by area, and shop. Recently, Oden is also sold at convenience stores.

[[Tonjiru]]

CATEGORIES: Soups, Japanese food

Tonjiru is a Japanese soup. This soup is cooked to boil miso, potatoes, carrots, burdocks, pork(see blow).It is a rare for Japanese soup to use pork. It stays hot, so it is popular in winter. 

==Recipe==              

1. Cut vegetables (potatoes, carrots and burdocks, etc...)and Pork to eat easy.

2. Boil them in soup stock at high heat.

3. Add miso to taste.

4. Add cut long green onions.

==History==            

Tonjiru probably began to cook from the Meiji era onward 1. In the Asuka era, the Imperial court banned to eat meat. So, people could not eat meat, but boar meats were not banned, and they eat it as a Botannnabe. Therefore, it is said that Tonjiru is based on Botannnabe.

==Local ingredients2==
