[[Bob Lanier]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Mayors of Houston, US Democratic Party politicians

Bob Lanier (March 10, 1925 – December 20, 2014) was an American businessman and politician. He served as mayor of the city of Houston, Texas from 1992 to 1998. Lanier was born in Baytown, Texas.

On December 20, 2014, Lanier died at the age of 89 in Houston, Texas from natural causes.

[[Robert Wolfe]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2014 deaths, American historians, American people of World War II, Deaths from natural causes, Writers from Vermont

Robert Wolfe (March 2, 1921 – December 10, 2014) was an American historian and archivist. He was a World War II U.S. Army officer. He was a archivist of the US National Archives. He was wounded in both the Pacific and European Theaters of Operation. Wolfe was born in Burlington, Vermont.

Wolfe died in Washington, D.C. from natural causes, aged 93.

[[Right to housing]]

CATEGORIES: International law

The Right to housing is the idea that everyone should have the possibility to live somewhere, to housing and shelter free from homelessness. Many countries recognise it. It is also in  the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. This means it is part of international law.  

[[Personal identification number]]

CATEGORIES: Everyday life

A Personal identification number (abbreviated as PIN) is a number that is used to authenticate a user of a system. It is used to make sure only certain people can get, use, or change information in the system.

PINs were created to be used with automated teller machines. Once someone inserts a bank card into the machine, they would be asked to enter a PIN using the buttons on a keypad, and would only be allowed to get their money if they entered the corrected PIN. In a similar way, EMV technology makes use of PIN numbers to make sure only the person holding a credit card can make a transaction with it.

Early PIN numbers only consisted of digits. Today, some banks use PINs made of digits and letters. There are also many new technologies being created to be used instead of PINs, such as using fingerprint scanners.

[[David Ricardo]]

CATEGORIES: 1772 births, 1823 deaths, British economists, Infectious disease deaths in England, People from London

David Ricardo (18 April 1772 – 11 September 1823) was a British political economist. He was one of the main thinkers behind Classical economics, together with Thomas Malthus, Adam Smith and John Stuart Mill.  Today, he is mostly known for his theory of comparative advantage. This theory suggests that a nation should concentrate its resources only in industries where it is most internationally competitive and trade with other countries to obtain products not produced nationally.   Ricardo promoted the idea of extreme industry specialization by nations, to the point of dismantling internationally competitive and otherwise profitable industries.  In this thinking Ricardo assumed the existence of a national industry policy aimed at promoting some industries to the detriment of others. For Ricardo some form of Central Economic Planning was a given.

The Ricardian model of comparative advantage has been challenged by, among others, Joan Robinson and Piero Sraffa.  Nevertheless, it remains the cornerstone of the argument in favour of international free trade as a means of increasing economic prosperity.  The theory of comparative advantage was the forerunner of the push towards globalization via increased international trade, the guiding theme in economic policy currently promoted by the OECD and the World Trade Organization.

[[Torus]]

CATEGORIES: Three-dimensional shapes

A torus (plural: tori or toruses) is a tube shape that is similar to the surface of a doughnut or an inner tube. In geometry, a torus is obtained by rotating a circle in three dimensional space. To make a torus, the circle is rotated around a line (called the axis of rotation) that is in the same plane as the circle. Usually the line does not touch the circle, so the torus has a hole through the center, and the torus is called a ring torus. For a ring torus, the axis of rotation passes through the center of the hole. 

In topology, sizes don't matter, and a torus is any shape that has one hole through it. 

A toroid is a suface made by rotating any shape around a line, so a torus is one kind of toroid.

If the torus is filled to make a solid shape, it is called a solid torus. A solid torus is often simply called a torus. A solid torus is made by rotating a disk (a filled-in circle) around a line. Common objects that have the shape of a solid torus are a doughnut, a bagel and an O-ring.

The surface area of a torus is given by 

The volume of a solid torus is given by 

[[Sitor Situmorang]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2014 deaths, Indonesian writers, Poets

Sitor Situmorang (October 2, 1923 – December 21, 2014) was an Indonesian poet, essayist and writer of short stories. Situmorang was born in Harianboho, North Sumatra. He was educated in Jakarta. He worked as a journalist and literary critic. Situmorang was known for his poem Angkatan ’45 (The Generation of ’45).

On December 21, 2014, he died at the age of 91 at his home in Apeldoorn, Netherlands.

[[Udo Jürgens]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2014 deaths, Austrian composers, Austrian singers, Deaths from heart failure, Eurovision Song Contest winners, People from Klagenfurt, Pop singers, Swiss composers, Swiss singers

Udo Jürgens (born Udo Jürgen Bockelmann, 30 September 1934 – 21 December 2014) was an Austrian composer and singer of popular music whose career spans over fifty years. He wrote more than 800 songs and sold over 100 million records. In 2007 he additionally obtained Swiss citizenship. He was known for his song "Reach for the Stars".

Jürgens died on 21 December 2014 in Münsterlingen, Switzerland from acute heart failure at the age of 80.

[[2004 Republican National Convention]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 in New York (state), 21st century in Manhattan, United States presidential nominating conventions, United States Republican Party, 2000s in New York City

The 2004 Republican National Convention was the 2004 presidential nominating convention. It was for the Republican Party of the United States. George W. Bush and Dick Cheney won the presidential nomination at the convention.

It took place from August 30 to September 2, 2004 at Madison Square Garden in New York City. A tribute for Ronald Reagan was shown at the convention.

[[John Panozzo]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 1996 deaths, American rock drummers, Deaths from cirrhosis, Musicians from Chicago

John Anthony Panozzo (September 20, 1948 – July 16, 1996) was an American drummer. He was best known for his work with rock band Styx. 

[[1982 State of the Union Address]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 in the United States, Speeches by Ronald Reagan, January events, 1980s in Washington, D.C.

The 1982 State of the Union Address was given by President Ronald Reagan to a joint session of the 97th United States Congress. It was held on January 26, 1982. The speech was the first State of the Union address of President Reagan's first term.

The speech lasted 40 minutes and 14 seconds. It had 5154 words. The address was broadcast live on radio and television.

The Democratic Party response was delivered by Senator Donald Riegle (MI), Senator James Sasser (TN), Rep. Albert Gore Jr. (TN), Senator Robert Byrd (W.Va), Senator Edward Kennedy (MA), House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill III (MA), Senator Gary Hart (CO), Senator Paul Sarbanes (MD), Senator J. Bennett Johnston (LA), and Senator Alan Cranston (CA).

[[Thomas P. O'Neill III]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, American lawyers, Lieutenant Governors of Massachusetts, People from Cambridge, Massachusetts, US Democratic Party politicians, 20th-century American politicians

Thomas Phillip O'Neill III (born September 20, 1944) is an American politician and lawyer. He leads a public relations and government affairs firm called O'Neill and Associates in Boston. He is the son of Thomas Phillip "Tip" O'Neill, Jr., who was Speaker of the United States House of Representatives from 1977 to 1987. From 1975 to 1983, O'Neill was Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[[1983 State of the Union Address]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 in the United States, Speeches by Ronald Reagan, January events, 1980s in Washington, D.C.

The 1983 State of the Union address was given by President Ronald Reagan to a joint session of the 98th United States Congress on January 25, 1983. The speech was the second State of the Union address of President Reagan's first term.

The speech lasted about 46 minutes. It had 5554 words. The address was broadcast live on radio and television.

The Democratic Party response was delivered by Senator Robert Byrd (WV), Senator Paul Tsongas (MA), Senator Bill Bradley (NJ), Senator Joe Biden (DE), Rep. Tom Daschle (SD), Rep. Barbara Kennelly (CT), House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill III (MA), Rep. George Miller (CA), Rep. Les AuCoin (OR), Rep. Paul Simon (IL), Rep. Timothy Wirth (CO), and Rep. Bill Hefner (NC).

[[1984 State of the Union Address]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 in the United States, Speeches by Ronald Reagan, January events, 1980s in Washington, D.C.

The 1984 State of the Union address was given by President Ronald Reagan to a joint session of the 98th United States Congress on January 25, 1984. The speech was the third State of the Union address of President Reagan's first term.

The speech lasted 43 minutes and 2 seconds and had 4931 words. The address was broadcast live on radio and television.

The Democratic Party response was delivered by Senator Joe Biden (DE), Sen. David Boren (OK), Senator Carl Levin (MI), Senator Max Baucus (MT), Senator Robert Byrd (WV), Senator Claiborne Pell (RI), Senator Walter Huddleston (KY), Rep. Dante B. Fascell (FL), Rep. Tom Harkin (IA), Rep. William Gray (PA), House Speaker Thomas O’Neill (MA), and Rep. Barbara Boxer (CA).

[[Susanne Alfvengren]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Susanne Alfvengren (born Susanne Irene Lund, 12 February 1959 in Visby, Gotland, Sweden) is a Swedish singer. In 1984, she had a hit with När vi rör varann (Sometimes When We Touch). Another of her hit songs was Magneter. She competed in Melodifestivalen 2009 with the song Du är älskad där du går, whih was knocked out of the semifinal. In 1986-1987, she scored a vocal duet hit with Mikael Rickfors, with the song Som stormen river öppet hav.

[[1985 State of the Union Address]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 in the United States, Speeches by Ronald Reagan, February events, 1980s in Washington, D.C.

The 1985 State of the Union address was given by President Ronald Reagan to a joint session of the 99th United States Congress on February 6, 1985 (Reagan's birthday). The speech was the first State of the Union address of President Reagan's second term, and his fifth altogether.  

He stated, "Our progress began not in Washington, DC, but in the hearts of our families, communities, workplaces, and voluntary groups which, together, are unleashing the invincible spirit of one great nation under God."    He believed that volunteerism was a key element to the American community.

The president proclaimed the Reagan Doctrine and talked about taxes, reducing the federal deficit and the Strategic Defense Initiative, among other things.

The speech lasted about 40 minutes and had 4,955 words. The address was broadcast live on radio and television.

The Democratic Party response was delivered by Governor Bill Clinton of Arkansas,  Governor Bob Graham of Florida and House Speaker Tip O'Neill.

[[1986 State of the Union Address]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 in the United States, Speeches by Ronald Reagan, February events, 1980s in Washington, D.C.

The 1986 State of the Union address was given by President Ronald Reagan to a joint session of the 99th United States Congress on February 4, 1986. The speech was the second State of the Union address of President Reagan's second term.

Reagan was the only president to have postponed his State of the Union Address. On January 28, 1986, he planned to give his address, but after learning of the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster, he postponed it for a week and addressed the nation on the day's events. This was the only time that the State of the Union address had to be postponed because of an event.

The speech lasted for about 31 minutes and had 3,514 words. The address was broadcast live on radio and television.

The Democratic Party response was delivered by Senator George Mitchell (ME), Lt. Gov. Harriett Woods (MO), Gov. Charles Robb (VA), Rep. Thomas Daschle (SD) and Rep. William Gray (PA)

[[1988 State of the Union Address]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 in the United States, Speeches by Ronald Reagan, January events, 1980s in Washington, D.C.

The 1988 State of the Union address was given by President Ronald Reagan to a joint session of the 100th United States Congress on January 25, 1988. The speech was the last State of the Union address of President Reagan's second term. Donald Hodel, the Secretary of the Interior, served as the designated survivor.

[[1987 State of the Union Address]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 in the United States, Speeches by Ronald Reagan, January events, 1980s in Washington, D.C.

The 1987 State of the Union address was given by President Ronald Reagan to a joint session of the 100th United States Congress on January 27, 1987. The speech was the third State of the Union address of President Reagan's second term. 

Reagan said, "The Soviet Union says it wants a peaceful settlement in Afghanistan, yet it continues a brutal war and props up a regime whose days are clearly numbered. We are ready to support a political solution that guarantees the rapid withdrawal of all Soviet troops and genuine self-determination for the Afghan people."  He ended with, "But now at length I have the happiness to know that it is a rising and not a setting Sun." Well, you can bet it's rising because, my fellow citizens, America isn't finished. Her best days have just begun." 

The speech lasted 34 minutes and 39 seconds and had 3847 words. The address was broadcast live on radio and television.

The Democratic Party response was delivered by Senator Robert Byrd (WV), and House Speaker Jim Wright (TX)

[[Billie Whitelaw]]

CATEGORIES: BAFTA Award winning actors, 1932 births, 2014 deaths, Actors from Bradford, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, People from Coventry

Billie Honor Whitelaw, CBE (6 June 1932 – 21 December 2014) was an English actress. 

Whitelaw was born in Coventry and was raised in Bradford. She was known for working with Samuel Beckett. Whitelaw was known for her roles in The Omen and in Hot Fuzz.

Whitelaw died in Hampstead, London, England, aged 82.

[[The Interview (2014 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 movies, American comedy movies, American action movies, Movies set in South Korea

The Interview is a 2014 American political action comedy movie directed by Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg. It stars James Franco, Seth Rogen, Lizzy Caplan, and Randall Park. It was set to be released on December 25, 2014, but the movie was cancelled due to threats from North Korea. The movie was released on demand and on YouTube.

[[This Is the End]]

CATEGORIES: 2013 movies, American comedy movies, Apocalyptic movies, Dystopian movies

This Is the End is a 2013 American disaster comedy movie directed by Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg. It stars James Franco, Seth Rogen, Jonah Hill, Jay Baruchel, Danny McBride, Craig Robinson, and Emma Watson. It was released on June 12, 2013 and re-released on September 6, 2013. 

[[The Polar Express (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 movies, 2004 animated movies, 2004 computer-animated movies, American animated movies, American comedy movies, American musical movies, American fantasy movies, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Robert Zemeckis, Uncanny valley

The Polar Express is a 2004 American computer animated musical fantasy movie directed by Robert Zemeckis. It was produced by Tom Hanks. It is based on the book, The Polar Express. It stars Tom Hanks, Daryl Sabara, Eddie Deezen, Jimmy Bennett, Steven Tyler, Nona Gaye, and Michael Jeter. It was released on November 10, 2004.

[[Richard Dysart]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2015 deaths, Actors from Boston, Massachusetts, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Disease-related deaths in California, Emmy Award winning actors

Richard A. Dysart (March 30, 1929 – April 5, 2015) was an American actor. He was best known for his role as Leland McKenzie on the NBC legal drama L.A. Law. Dysart was born in Boston, Massachusetts. He won an Emmy Award in 1992.

Dysart died at home in Santa Monica, California after a long illness, aged 86.

[[Roy L. Dennis]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 1978 deaths, People from California

Roy Lee "Rocky" Dennis (December 4, 1961 – October 4, 1978) was an American boy who had craniodiaphyseal dysplasia, an extremely rare, sclerotic bone disease. The condition usually results in neurological disorders and death during childhood. His body was donated to UCLA Medical Center after he died.

[[Michael Cimino]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2016 deaths, Academy Award winning directors, Deaths from heart failure, Golden Globe Award winning directors, Movie directors from New York City, Movie producers from New York City, Screenwriters from New York City, Yale University alumni

Michael Cimino (tʃ chi; February 3, 1939 – July 2, 2016) was an American movie director, screenwriter, producer and author. He was best known for directing, producing and co-writing the 1978 Academy Award-winning movie The Deer Hunter, and for writing and directing 1980s financial failure Heaven's Gate.

Cimino was found dead of heart failure on July 2, 2016 in his bed Los Angeles, California, aged 77.

[[William Friedkin]]

CATEGORIES: Academy Award winning actors, Golden Globe Award winning actors, 1935 births, Living people, Movie directors from Chicago, Movie producers from Chicago, Screenwriters from Chicago

William Friedkin (born August 29, 1935) is an American movie director, producer and screenwriter. He was best known for directing The French Connection in 1971 and The Exorcist in 1973. He won the Academy Award for Best Director. 

Some of his other movie include Sorcerer, The Brink's Job, Cruising, Deal of the Century, To Live and Die in L.A., Jade, Rules of Engagement, The Hunted, Bug, and Killer Joe.

[[Horacio Ferrer]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Uruguayan writers, Poets, People from Montevideo

Horacio Ferrer (June 2, 1933 - December 21, 2014) is a Uruguayan poet, broadcaster, reciter and tango lyricist.  He is known for the lyrics he wrote for Astor Piazzolla’s tangos such as Balada para un loco and Chiquilín de Bachín.

[[Trevor Peacock]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from dementia, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, Actors from London

Trevor Peacock (19 May 1931 – 8 March 2021) was an English stage and television character actor. He also was a screenwriter and songwriter. He was known for his role as Jim Trott in the BBC comedy series The Vicar of Dibley.

Peacock was born in Tottenham, London, the son of Alexandria and Victor Edward Peacock.

Peacock was diagnosed with dementia in 2009. He died from the disease on 8 March 2021 in London, aged 89.

[[SummerSlam (2007)]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 in professional wrestling, Sports in New Jersey, SummerSlam, 2007 in New Jersey, August events

SummerSlam (2007) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). It was held on August 26, 2007 at Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, New Jersey. It was the twentieth SummerSlam event held by the WWE. 

The main event saw John Cena defeat Randy Orton and successfully defended his WWE Championship.

[[Towe Jaarnek]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Swedish singers, Living people

Towe Jaarnek, born 13 June 1965, is a Swedish singer. She participated at Melodifestivalen 1991 with the song Ett liv med dej. The song ended up 2nd. In 1992, reorded the vocal duet More Than a Game together with Peter Jöback. That song was the official song for the 1992 European Football Championship. The tournament was played in Sweden.

[[Crested penguin]]

CATEGORIES: Penguins

The term crested penguin is the common name of species of penguins of the genus Eudyptes. All are black and white penguins with yellow crests, red bills and eyes. They are found on subantarctic islands in the world's southern oceans. All lay two eggs, but raise only one young per breeding season. The first egg laid is much smaller than the second.

Different experts disagree on how many species there are. They include the rockhopper penguins.

A Chatham Islands species may have become extinct in the 19th century. 

[[Peter Jöback]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Peter Arne Jöback, born 4 June 1971 in Stockholm, Sweden, is a Swedish singer as well as actor and musical artist.

[[Pernilla Wahlgren]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, Swedish singers

[[Laleh Pourkarim]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Laleh Pourkarim (لاله پورکریم, lɒːle-je puːɾkæɾiːm; born 10 June 1982, is a Swedish singer-songwriter and former actress. After a short-lasting acting career, she entered the music industry in 2005 with her self-titled debut album. It peaked at number one in Sweden, and became the highest selling album of the year.

[[Anders Wejryd]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Archbishops of Uppsala, Living people

Anders Harald Wejryd, born 8 August 1948 in Falköping, Sweden is a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He was appointed Bishop of Växjö in 1995. In March 2006, he was elected Archbishop of Uppsala and primate of the Church of Sweden. He took office in September of the same year. He left office in 2014, and was replaced with Antje Jackelén.

[[Bertil Werkström]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2010 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Bertil Werkström, born 9 June 1928 in Lund Cathedral Parish, Sweden, dead 10 July 2010 in Farsta Parish, Sweden was the Archbishop of Uppsala between 1983–1993. His wife was named Britta. Serving as Archbishop he supported ecumenism In international affairs he supported sanctions against the Apartheid rule in South Africa. In 1984 he also maintained that homosexuality was "against the orders of creation."

In 1991, he visited Rome to commemorate the 600th anniversary of the canonization of Bridget of Sweden together with the Pope of the Roman Catholic Church.

[[K. G. Hammar]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Archbishops of Uppsala, Living people

Karl Gustav Hilding Hammar, born 18 February  1943 in Hässleholm), Sweden, commonly referred to as K. G. Hammar, is a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He was the Archbishop of Uppsala, head of the Church of Sweden, from 1997 to 2006. During his tenure as archbishop, the Church of Sweden and the government separated on 21 January 2000.

[[Yngve Brilioth]]

CATEGORIES: 1889 births, 1959 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Yngve Brilioth, born 12 July 1891 in Västra Ed, Sweden, dead 27 April 1959 in Uppsala, Sweden was a professor for church history, and later for Practical theology in Uppsala, Turku and Lund. He served as the Lutheran Bishop of Växjö between 1938 and 1950. Between 1950 and 1958, he was the Lutheran Archbishop of Uppsala. He was also the author of a history of the Oxford Movement, which written to coincide with its centenary in 1933. He married the daughter of a predecessor, Nathan Söderblom.

[[Erling Eidem]]

CATEGORIES: 1880 births, 1972 deaths, People from Gothenburg, Archbishops of Uppsala

Erling Eidem, born 23 April 1880 in Gothenburg, Sweden, dead 14 April 1972 in Vänersborg, Sweden was a Swedish theologian. He served as the Lutheran archbishop of Uppsala between 1931 and 1950.

[[Nathan Söderblom]]

CATEGORIES: 1866 births, 1931 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Lars Olof Jonathan Söderblom (ˈnɑːtan ˈsøːdɛrblʊm), born 15 January 1866 in Trönö, Sweden, dead 12 July 1931 in Uppsala, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He was the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala between 1914-1931 In 1930, he was awarded the 1930 Nobel Peace Prize.

[[Johan August Ekman]]

CATEGORIES: 1845 births, 1913 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Johan August Ekman, born 26 November 1845, in Hjälstad, Sweden, dead 30 November 1913 in Uppsala, Sweden was the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala between 1900-1913. He also served as bishop of Västerås between 1898 and 1900.

[[Anton Niklas Sundberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1818 births, 1900 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Anton Niklas Sundberg, born 27 May 1818 in Uddevalla, Sweden, dead  2 February 1900 in Uppsala, Sweden, was a Lutheran clergyman. He served as the Church of Sweden archbishop of Uppsala between 1870-1900.

[[Henrik Reuterdahl]]

CATEGORIES: 1795 births, 1870 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Henrik Reuterdahl, born 11 September 1795 in Malmö, Sweden, dead 28 June 1870  in Uppsala, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He servred as the Church of Sweden archbishop of Uppsala from 1856 until his 1870 death.

[[Carl Fredrik af Wingård]]

CATEGORIES: 1781 births, 1851 deaths, People from Stockholm, Archbishops of Uppsala

Carl Fredrik af Wingård, born 26 September 1781 in Stockholm, Sweden, dead 19 September 1851 in Sunnersta, Sweden was a Swedish politician and Lutheran clergyman. He verved as the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala, between 1839 and 1851.

[[Johan Olof Wallin]]

CATEGORIES: 1779 births, 1839 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Johan Olof Wallin, born 15 October 1779 in Yttre Skomsarby, Sweden, dead 30 June 1839 in Uppsala, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He was the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala between 1837-1839. He also wrote many Christian songs/hymns.

[[Liquid nitrogen]]

CATEGORIES: Chemical elements

Liquid nitrogen is nitrogen at a very low temperature. It is usually produced by a process known as fractional distillation of air. At atmospheric pressure (normal pressure) nitrogen boils at −196 °C  (77 K; −321 °F).

Nitrogen was first made into a liquid at Jagiellonian University on 15 April 1883. Zygmunt Wróblewski and Karol Olszewski were the first scientists to liquefy nitrogen, oxygen and carbon dioxide. During World War II the production of liquid nitrogen became common. This lowered the cost to produce it. After the war new uses were found for liquid gases. Liquid nitrogen became a major gas in the US.

[[Carl von Rosenstein]]

CATEGORIES: 1766 births, 1836 deaths, People from Uppsala, Archbishops of Uppsala

Carl von Rosenstein, born Carl Aurivillius on 13 May 1766 in Uppsala, Sweden; dead 2 December 1836 at Brunna Mansion, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He was the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala from 1819 to 1836. Before that he served as the Bishop of Linköping from 1809 to 1819. His family tree included scientists like Sven Magnus Aurivillius and Per Olof Christopher Aurivillius. The "von Rosenstein" name was his mother's family name and came through an adoption. His grandfather was Nils Rosén von Rosenstein, Uppsala University professor of medicine.

In addition to being archbishop, he was also a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences from 1809. From 1819, he was also a member of the Swedish Academy from 1819. He belonged to the Swedish nobility.

[[Jacob Axelsson Lindblom]]

CATEGORIES: 1746 births, 1819 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Jacob Axelsson Lindblom, born 27 July 1746, in Skeda, Sweden, dead 15 February 1819, in Uppsala, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He served as the Church of Sweden archbishop of Uppsala between 1805-1819.

[[Uno von Troil]]

CATEGORIES: 1746 births, 1803 deaths, People from Stockholm, Archbishops of Uppsala

Uno von Troil, born 24 February 1746 in Stockholm, Sweden, dead 27 July 1803 at Sätra brunn, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He was the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala between 1786-1803. He was the son of Samuel Troilius, who had also been archbishop.

[[Carl Fredrik Mennander]]

CATEGORIES: 1712 births, 1786 deaths, People from Stockholm, Archbishops of Uppsala

Carl Fredrik Mennander (sometimes modernised as Karl Fredrik Mennander, often just C.F. Mennander; 19 July 1712, Stockholm, Sweden,  22 May 1786, Uppsala, Sweden) was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He was the Bishop of Turku between 1757-1775. He then served as the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala from 1775 until his 1786 death.

[[Magnus Beronius]]

CATEGORIES: 1692 births, 1775 deaths, People from Uppsala, Archbishops of Uppsala

Magnus Olai Beronius, born 18 October 1692 in Uppsala, Sweden, dead 18 May 1775 in Uppsala, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He was the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala from 1764 until his 1775.

[[Samuel Troilius]]

CATEGORIES: 1706 births, 1764 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Samuel Troilius, born 22 May 1706 in Stora Skedvi, Sweden, dead 18 January 1764 in Uppsala, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He served as the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala from 1758 until his death 1764.

[[Henric Benzelius]]

CATEGORIES: 1689 births, 1758 deaths, Archbishops of Uppsala

Henric Benzelius, born 7 August 1689 in Strängnäs, Sweden, dead 20 May 1758 in Uppsala, Sweden was a Swedish Lutheran clergyman. He serrved as the Bishop of Lund from 1744 to 1747. He was then the Church of Sweden Archbishop of Uppsala from 1747 until his 1758 death.

[[Carl Bildt]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Swedish diplomats, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Nils Daniel Carl Bildt (born 15 July 1949) in Halmstad, Sweden, is a Swedish politician and diplomat who was Prime Minister of Sweden from 1991 to 1994.  

He was the leader of the Moderate Party from 1986 to 1999. He also served as Sweden's Minister for Foreign Affairs from 2006 to 2014. 

[[Ola Ullsten]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2018 deaths, Ambassadors of Sweden, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Stig Kjell Olof (Ola) Ullsten, (23 June 1931 in Umeå, Sweden – 28 May 2018) was a Swedish former politician and diplomat. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden from 1978 to 1979 He was also the leader of the Liberal People's Party from 1978 to 1983. He also served as Deputy Prime Minister briefly in 1978 and then again from 1980 to 1982. He was also the Swedish foreign minister between 1979 and 1982.

Ullsten died on 28 May 2018 at the age of 86.

[[Axel Pehrsson-Bramstorp]]

CATEGORIES: 1883 births, 1954 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Axel Alarik Pehrsson-Bramstorp, born Axel Alarik Pehrsson, 19 August 1883, dead 19 February 1954, was a Swedish politician. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden for a few months during mid 1936.

[[Felix Hamrin]]

CATEGORIES: 1875 births, 1937 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Felix Teodor Hamrin, born 14 January 1875, dead 27 November 1937, was a Swedish politician. He was the leader of the liberal Freeminded People's Party. He also served as Prime Minister of Sweden from 6 August to 24 September 1932.

[[Carl Gustaf Ekman]]

CATEGORIES: 1872 births, 1945 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Carl Gustaf Ekman, born 6 October 1872, dead 15 June 1945, was a Swedish politician. He was a member of the Swedish parliament 1911-1932, in both the lower and the upper houses. Between 1924-1932, he led the Freeminded People's Party. He served as the  Prime Minister of Sweden between 1926-1928 and again between 1930-1932.

[[Arvid Lindman]]

CATEGORIES: 1862 births, 1936 deaths, Admirals, Swedish businesspeople, Government ministers of Sweden, People from Uppsala, Prime Ministers of Sweden, Swedish military people

Salomon ''Arvid'' Achates Lindman, born 19 September 1862, dead 9 December 1936, was a Swedish rear admiral, industrialist and conservative politician. He served as the  Prime Minister of Sweden from 1906 to 1911, and then again from 1928 to 1930.

[[Rickard Sandler]]

CATEGORIES: 1884 births, 1964 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Rickard Johannes Sandler, born 29 January 1884, dead 12 November 1964) was a Swedish Social Democratic politician. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden between 24 January 1925 and 7 June 1926

[[Nils Edén]]

CATEGORIES: 1871 births, 1945 deaths, Swedish historians, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Nils Edén, born 25 August 1871, dead 16 June 1945, was a Swedish historian and liberal politician. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden between 1917-1920.

[[Ernst Trygger]]

CATEGORIES: 1857 births, 1943 deaths, Academics, Government ministers of Sweden, Jurists, Politicians from Stockholm, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Ernst Trygger, (born 27 October 1857 - 23 September 1943) was a Swedish jurist professor and conservative politician. He was the Prime Minister of Sweden from 1923 to 1924 He was also the Swedish foreign minister from 1928 to 1930 in the cabinet of Arvid Lindman. He was a member of the first chamber of the Swedish parliament from 1898 to 1937. He was also leader of the conservatives in that chamber from 1913 to 1933.

[[Oscar von Sydow]]

CATEGORIES: 1873 births, 1936 deaths, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Oscar Fredrik von Sydow, born 12 1873, dead 19 August 1936, was a Swedish politician. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden from February 23 to October 13, 1921.

[[Gerhard Louis De Geer]]

CATEGORIES: 1854 births, 1935 deaths, Prime Ministers of Sweden, Swedish nobility

Gerhard Louis De Geer, born 27 November 1854, dead 25 February 1935, was a Swedish baron and politician. He served in the first chamber of the Swedish parliament between 1901-1914. He was also the governor of Kristianstad County between 1905-1923. Also, he served as the Prime Minister of Sweden between 1920-1921.

[[Carl Swartz]]

CATEGORIES: 1858 births, 1926 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Carl Johan Gustaf Swartz, born 5 June 1858, dead 6 November 1926, was a Swedish right-wing politician. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden from 30 March to 19 October 1917. He was also the Swedish Minister for Finance from 1906 to 1911. He married Dagmar Lundström in 1886, with whom he had three children, Erik, Brita and Olof.

[[Hjalmar Hammarskjöld]]

CATEGORIES: 1862 births, 1953 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Knut Hjalmar Leonard Hammarskjöld, born 4 February 1862, dead 12 October 1953, was a Swedish politician, scholar, cabinet minister and Member of Parliament from 1923 to 1938 (first chamber). He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden from 1914 to 1917.

In 1890, he married Agnes Almquist (1866–1940). The couple had four sons: Bo, Åke, Sten and Dag.

[[Karl Staaff]]

CATEGORIES: 1860 births, 1915 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Lawyers, Politicians from Stockholm, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Karl Albert Staaff, born 21 January 1860, dead 4 October 1915, was a Swedish liberal politician and lawyer. He was the chairman of the Liberal Coalition Party between 1907-1915. He served twice as the Prime Minister of Sweden, first between 1905-1906 and then again between 1911-1914.

[[Christian Lundeberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1842 births, 1911 deaths, Legislative speakers, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Christian Lundeberg, born 14 July 1842, dead 10 November 1911, was a Swedish politician. He served as Prime Minister of Sweden from 2 August to 7 November 1905.

[[Johan Ramstedt]]

CATEGORIES: 1852 births, 1935 deaths, Judges, Politicians from Stockholm, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Johan Olof Ramstedt (born 7 November 1852 -15 March 1935) was a Swedish politician. He was the Prime Minister of Sweden from April to August 1905.

[[Erik Gustaf Boström]]

CATEGORIES: 1842 births, 1907 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Politicians from Stockholm, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Erik Gustaf Bernhard Boström, born 11 February 1842, dead 21 February 1907, was a Swedish landowner and politician. He was a member of the Swedish Parliament between 1876 and 1907. He was the longest-serving Prime Minister of Sweden of the 19th century. He served in that office twice, first from 1891 to 1900. Then he served again from 1902 to 1905. He was also known as E.G. Boström or E. Gust. Boström.

[[Fredrik von Otter]]

CATEGORIES: 1833 births, 1910 deaths, Admirals, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden, Swedish military people, Swedish nobility

Fredrik Wilhelm von Otter, born 11 April 1833, dead  9 March 1910, was a Swedish friherre, and naval officer, as well as a politician. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden from 1900 to 1902.

[[Gustaf Åkerhielm]]

CATEGORIES: 1833 births, 1900 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Politicians from Stockholm, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Friherre Johan Gustaf Nils Samuel Akerhielm of Margaretelund (24 July 1833 - 2 April 1900) was a Swedish politician, baron and landowner. He was a member of the Swedish parliament twice, first from 1859 to 1866 and then again from 1870 to 1900. He was also Sweden's Minister of Finance from 1874 to 1875, and Minister for Foreign Affairs in 1889. Also, he served as Swedish Prime Minister from 1889 to 1891.

He was married to Ulrika Gyldenstolpe in 1860. The couple had three children.

[[Gillis Bildt]]

CATEGORIES: 1820 births, 1894 deaths, Ambassadors of Sweden, Generals, Prime Ministers of Sweden, Swedish military people, Swedish nobility

Didrik Anders Gillis Bildt, born 16 October 1820, dead 22 October 1894, was a Swedish parliamentarian, general, ambassador and baron. He served as the prime minister of Sweden between 1888–1889.

[[Robert Themptander]]

CATEGORIES: 1844 births, 1897 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Politicians from Stockholm, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Oscar Robert Themptander, born 14 February 1844, dead 30 January 1897) was a Swedish politician and public official. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden from 1884 to 1888 during the reign of King Oscar II. He was also the Governor of Stockholm County between 1888 to 1896. Also, he served as Sweden's Minister for Finance.

[[Carl Johan Thyselius]]

CATEGORIES: 1811 births, 1891 deaths, Civil servants, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Carl Johan Thyselius (8 June 1811 - 11 January 1891) was a Swedish politician and government official. He served as Justice Councillor (1856-1860), Minister for Ecclesiastical Affairs (1860-1863), Minister for Civil Affairs (responsible for trade, industry and ship transport (1875-80), and he served as the Prime Minister from 1883 to 1884.

[[Arvid Posse]]

CATEGORIES: 1820 births, 1901 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden, Swedish nobility

Count Arvid Rutger Fredriksson Posse, born 15 February 1820, dead 24 April 1901, was a Swedish politician. He served as the Prime Minister of Sweden from 1880 to 1883.

[[Louis Gerard De Geer]]

CATEGORIES: 1818 births, 1896 deaths, Government ministers of Sweden, Prime Ministers of Sweden, Swedish nobility, Swedish writers

Baron Louis Gerard De Geer of Finspång, born 18 July 1818, dead 24 September 1896, was a Swedish statesman and writer. Between 1876 and 1880, he was the first Prime Minister of Sweden

[[Gustaf V]]

CATEGORIES: 1858 births, 1950 deaths, Kings and Queens of Sweden

Gustaf V (Oscar Gustaf Adolf, born 16 June 1858, dead 29 October 1950, was a Swedish monarch. He was the King of Sweden from 1907 until his death in 1950.

[[Charles XV]]

CATEGORIES: 1826 births, 1872 deaths, Kings and Queens of Sweden, People from Stockholm

Charles XV & IV also Carl (Carl Ludvig Eugen); Swedish and Norwegian: Karl, born 3 May 1826, dead 18 September 1872, was a Swedish monarch. He was the King of Sweden (Charles XV) and Norway (Charles IV) from 1859 until his death in 1872.

[[Oscar I of Sweden]]

CATEGORIES: 1799 births, 1859 deaths, Kings and Queens of Sweden

Oscar I (born Joseph François Oscar Bernadotte 4 July 1799, dead 8 July 1859, was a Swedish monarch. He was the King of Sweden and Norway from 1844 until his death in 1859.

[[Charles XIV John of Sweden]]

CATEGORIES: 1763 births, 1844 deaths, Kings and Queens of Sweden

Charles XIV & III John, also Carl John, Swedish and Norwegian: Carl Johan (26 January 1763 – 8 March 1844) was a Swedish monarch. He was the King of Sweden (as Charles XIV John) and King of Norway (as Charles III John) from 1818 until his 1844 death. Before he became Swedish royalty, he had also been the Sovereign Prince of Pontecorvo from 1806 until 1810, but then stopped using that title.

[[Östen Undén]]

CATEGORIES: 1886 births, 1974 deaths, Swedish academics, Civil servants, Government ministers of Sweden, Jurists, Prime Ministers of Sweden

Bo Östen Undén JD (25 August 1886 in Karlstad - 14 January 1974 in Stockholm) was a Swedish academic, civil servant and Social Democratic politician. He was acting Prime Minister of Sweden 6 October 1946 – 11 October 1946 following the death of Per Albin Hansson.

[[Ulf Lundell]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Musicians from Stockholm, Writers from Stockholm

Ulf Lundell (born 20 November 1949 in Södermalm, Stockholm, Sweden, full name Ulf Gerhard Lundell) is a Swedish writer, poet, songwriter, composer, musician and artist.

[[Tomas Ledin]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Tomas Folke Jonas Ledin (ˈtʰʊmas ˈfɔl.ˈkɛ ˈjuː.ˈnas lɛˈdiːn, born 25 February 1952, in Rätan, Sweden) is a Swedish singer, songwriter, guitarist, and producer. He grew up in the town of Sandviken in Sweden.

[[Ann-Louise Hanson]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Ann-Louise Hanson, born 4 April 1944 in Kristianstad, Sweden is a Swedish singer She has been involved in the music industry since 1956.

[[Towa Carson]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Towa Carson (actual name Birgit Rose-Marie Anlert, née Carlsson), born on 31 March 1936 in Eskilstuna, Sweden, is a Swedish schlager singer. She debuted in 1954, and scored most successes during the 1950s and 60s. She recorded many vocal duets with Lasse Lönndahl. She has also participated in Swedish Eurovision Song Contest) preselection Melodifestivalen.

[[Alice Tegnér]]

CATEGORIES: 1864 births, 1943 deaths, Swedish musicians

Alice Charlotta Tegnér, born 12 March 1864, dead 26 May 1943, was a Swedish music teacher, poet and composer. During the late 19th and early 20th century, she composed several children's songs.

[[Viktor Rydberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1828 births, 1895 deaths, Swedish writers

Abraham ''Viktor'' Rydberg (born 18 December 1828 in Jönköping, Sweden, died 21 September 1895 in Djursholm, Sweden) was a Swedish writer. Between 1877-1895 he was a member of the Swedish Academy.

[[Abdur Rahman Biswas]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, Muslims, Presidents of Bangladesh, Bangladeshi Muslims

Abdur Rahman Biswas (1 September 1926 – 3 November 2017) was a Bangladeshi politician. He was the 11th President of Bangladesh during 1991 to 1996.

Biswas died on 3 November 2017 at a hospital in Dhaka of respiratory failure, at the age of 91.

[[Charles XIII of Sweden]]

CATEGORIES: 1748 births, 1818 deaths, Kings and Queens of Sweden

Charles XIII & II also Carl, Karl XIII (born 7 October 1748 in Stockholm, Sweden, dead 5 February 1818 in, was a Swedish monarch. He was the King of Sweden (as Charles XIII) from 1809 and King of Norway (as Charles II) from 1814 until his 1818 death. He was the second son of King Adolf Frederick of Sweden and Louisa Ulrika of Prussia, sister of Frederick II of Prussia.

While known as King Charles XIII in Sweden, he was actually the seventh Swedish king by that name, as Charles IX (reigned 1604–1611) had adopted his numeral after studying a fictitious history of Sweden.

[[Alberto Breccia Guzzo]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2014 deaths, Uruguayan politicians, Uruguayan lawyers, People from Montevideo

Alberto Breccia (3 July 1946 – 1 December 2014) was a Uruguayan politician and lawyer. He served in the Chamber of Deputies of Uruguay representing the Broad Front party. Breccia was born in Montevideo, Uruguay.

Breccia died in Montevideo, Uruguay, aged 68.

[[Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden]]

CATEGORIES: People from Stockholm, Kings and Queens of Sweden, 1778 births, 1837 deaths

Gustav IV Adolf or Gustav IV Adolph, born 1 November 1778, dead 7 February 1837 was a Swedish monarch. He was the King of Sweden from 1792 until he abdicated in 1809.

[[Gustav III of Sweden]]

CATEGORIES: 1746 births, 1792 deaths, Kings and Queens of Sweden

Gustav III (24 January – 29 March 1792Dates) was King of Sweden from 1771 until he was shot to death death in 1792. He was the eldest son of King Adolph Frederick and Queen Louise Ulrika, who was a sister of Frederick the Great, King of Prussia.

[[Fritz Sdunek]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2014 deaths, Boxers, Coaches, Sportspeople from Mecklenburg-Vorpommern

Fritz Sdunek (pronounced free-ts zdoo-neck, April 18, 1947 – December 22, 2014) was a German professional boxing trainer and former amateur boxer.

Sdunek was one of the most successful and famous boxing trainers. He trained, among others, such world champions as Wladimir and Vitali Klitschko and Dariusz Michalczewski. He was born in Lüssow, Germany.

Sdunek died in Hamburg on December 22, 2014, at the age of 67.

[[Jan Malmsjö]]

CATEGORIES: Swedish actors, Swedish singers, 1932 births, Living people

Jan Wilhelm Malmsjö, born 29 May 1932, is a Swedish stage and film actor, musical star and singer. He is married to Marie Göranzon and father to Jonas Malmsjö.

[[Alan Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Alumni of the University of Oxford, Former Labour MPs (UK), Politicians from Glamorgan

Alan John Williams (14 October 1930 – 21 December 2014) was a British Labour Party politician. He was the Member of Parliament (MP) for Swansea West from 1964 to 2010.

Williams was born in Caerphilly. He died in London at the age of 84 from a stroke on 21 December 2014.

[[Maia Hirasawa]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Living people, Swedish musicians

Maia Hirasawa, born May 5, 1980 in Sollentuna, Sweden, is a Swedish-Japanese singer-songwriter.

[[Morteza Ahmadi]]

CATEGORIES: Iranian actors, 1924 births, 2014 deaths, Iranian writers, Iranian singers, People from Tehran

Morteza Haj Seyed Ahmadi (مرتضی حاج سید احمدی‎; 1 November 1924 – 21 December 2014) was an Iranian actor, singer and writer. Ahmadi was known for his works in Autobus, Madrak-e Jorm and Khane-kharab. He was born in Tehran.

Ahmadi died on 21 December 2014 at his private house in Tehran, aged 90.

[[Karin Kock-Lindberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1891 births, 1976 deaths, Swedish economists, Government ministers of Sweden, Swedish academics, Swedish scientists

Karin Kock-Lindberg, née Kock, born 2 July 1891, dead 28 July 1976, was a Swedish social democrat politician and professor of economics. In 1947 she became the first woman to hold a Ministerial position in Sweden. She also became the first female professor of national economy in Sweden. She was known as Karin Kock-Lindberg after marrying lawyer Hugo Lindberg in 1936.

[[Frank Truitt]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2014 deaths, Sportspeople from Columbus, Ohio

Frank Wilson Truitt, Jr., (April 4, 1925 – December 21, 2014) was an American coach and a veteran of World War II. Truitt helped coach the Ohio State men's basketball team to the 1960 NCAA Championship. Truitt was born in Columbus, Ohio.

Truitt died in Columbus, Ohio, aged 89.

[[Lim Xiaoqing]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, Swedish sportspeople, Badminton players

Lim Xiaoqing, born 15 August 1967, is a retired female badminton player. Originally from China, she later moved to Sweden.

She won three European Badminton Championships, one in the women's singles in 1994, and two in the women's doubles in 1992 and 1994. In 1995 she won the women's singles title at the All-England Championships. She then defeated Camilla Martin from Denmark in the final.

[[Jane Bown]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2014 deaths, English photographers, People from Herefordshire

Jane Hope Bown CBE (13 March 1925 – 21 December 2014) was an English photographer who worked for The Observer newspaper from 1949. Her portraits have been very popular to many critics. Bown was born in Eastnor, Herefordshire.

Bown died in London, aged 89.

[[Åke Johansson]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2014 deaths, Swedish footballers

Åke "Bajdoff" Johansson (19 March 1928 – 21 December 2014) was a Swedish football player. Johansson played as a center half in IFK Norrköping and capped 53 times for the national team between 1955-1965.

Johansson became Swedish champion with his club 6 times (1952, 1956, 1957, 1960, 1962 and 1963), won Guldbollen 1957 and was a member of the silver winning team in 1958 FIFA World Cup but didn't appeared in the final. He also capped one time for the national team in ice hockey. He died after a brief illness, on 21 December 2014.

[[Falköpings KIK]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 establishments in Sweden, Swedish football clubs

Falköpings KIK is a sports club in Falköping, Sweden. The club was established in 1976. In 2007, the women's soccer team played in the Swedish top division, Damallsvenskan.

[[IFK Vänersborg]]

CATEGORIES: 1903 establishments in Sweden, Bandy clubs in Sweden

IFK Vänersborg is a sports club in Vänersborg, Sweden. The club was established in 1903, and is most famous for its men's bandy successes. The club has played several seasons in the Swedish top division. During the 2014 World Cup the team played the final, losing 1-4 against Västerås SK.

[[Stefan Borsch]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Swedish singers, Living people

Stefan Borsch, born 19 January 1947 in Hagfors, Sweden, is a Swedish dansband singer. He originally sang for Öijwinds. From 1973, he sung for Vikingarna. After leaving Vikingarna, he began a solo career. He participated at the Swedish Melodifestivalen 1985 with the song "Sjung din sång", which was knocked out in the first round. In parallel to his solo albums, he also sang with Anders Engbergs until 1988. In 1989, he begun to appeari with Spotlight, later appearing under the name Stefan Borsch orkester. Under that name, they released albums until the band breakup in 1993 . Between 11 February 1995 and 4 December 1999 he was a member of Keith Elwins orkester. before ending his musical carrier in 1999

On 3 July 2004, he made an appearance in the Arvika Park together with Vikingarna during the band's final appearance.

[[Gripen Trollhättan BK]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 establishments in Europe, Bandy clubs in Sweden, 1930s establishments in Sweden

Gripen Trollhättan BK is a bandy club in Trollhättan, Sweden. The club was formed in 1936. The club was originally called Gripens BK, before changing name in 1988. The men's team played in the Swedish first division the seasons of 1973/1974, 2001/2002, 2002/2003 and 2004/2005. During the 2006/2007 season, the club managed to reach the top division again, where the club played during the 2007/2008. Their home ground is Slättbergshallen.

[[Ryan Shay]]

CATEGORIES: Sportspeople from Michigan, Deaths from myocardial infarction, 1979 births, 2007 deaths

Ryan Shay, born May 4, 1979 – dead 3 November 3, 2007 was an US professional long-distance runner. He was born in Ypsilanti, Michigan, USA. He attended the University of Notre Dame. He was married to Alicia Craig, who was also an American distance runner.

He won several USA championships titles.

[[The Rivieras]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s American music groups, Musical groups established in 1962, 1962 establishments in the United States, 20th-century establishments in Indiana, 1966 disestablishments in the United States

The Rivieras was a US rock and roll group. They mostly became famous for their hit song "California Sun".

[[Christina Lindberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Christina Lindberg, born 4 November  1968, is a Swedish country and dansband singer. She has sung together with Lasse Stefanz, and is probably most known for the song "De sista ljuva åren", which was a Svensktoppen hit from February 1989 and the upcoming 65 weeks, until the song left the chart in September 1990.

[[Olle Jönsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Olle Jönsson, born 1 December 1955, is a Swedish singer for the dansband Lasse Stefanz. The band was awarded a Grammis in the "Dansband of the year" in 1989. Earlier, he was also the band's drummer, until a wrist operation. In January 2007, Gunnar Nilsson replaced him as the band's drummer instead.

In November 2012, Olle Jönsson announced he would immediately leave the band. However, he reappeared on stage as the band's singer already the upcoming week.

[[Bill Bruford]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, English rock drummers, Musicians from Kent

William Scott "Bill" Bruford (born 17 May 1949 in Sevenoaks, Kent) is an English drummer, percussionist, composer, producer, and record label owner. He was the first drummer in the progressive rock group Yes, from 1968–1972. Bruford played in many other bands since the early 1970s. He was the drummer for Genesis in 1976 while they were on tour. Bruford was the drummer for progressive rock band King Crimson. Bruford now plays jazz, and has his own jazz group, Earthworks. He stopped performing in public in 2009. He still has two record labels, and continues to speak and write about music. His autobiography, Bill Bruford: The Autobiography, was published in early 2009.

[[Bertil Hallin]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Swedish musicians

Bertil Hallin, born 30 December 1931, is a Swedish church musician and music teacher. He as been active in Malmö. He participated as an expert in the hymn commission of 1969. It led to the creation of the 1986 Swedish hymnal.

[[Questioning (sexuality and gender)]]

CATEGORIES: Transgender

The questioning of one's status as a male, female or other (gender or gender identity), attraction to other people (sexual orientation) or both is often referred to in the LGBT community as just "questioning".

Questioning these aspects is a process of exploring things about oneself, which may make people unsure and worried about applying a label to themselves for different reasons.

The letter "Q" is often added to the end of the acronym LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender); the "Q" can refer to either queer or questioning. Many LGBT student groups and books include questioning in their books and literature; in the case of gay-straight alliances they do so in part so that students are not forced to label themselves or choose a sexual or gender identity.

According to the  American Psychological Association:

Some young people avoid "coming out of the closet" (telling others their sexual orientation) because of homophobic negative beliefs by other people. For some young people, admitting their sexual or gender identity can bring an end to this confusion. Those who receive support can often live happy and healthy lives. However, those who do not are more likely to have to deal with bullying, experiencing suicidal thoughts, and are more likely to engage in risky activities such as having unprotected sex (not using a condom), misuse drugs and become alcoholic. Questioning young people are at higher risk of these than their open LGBT peers.

An issue of anxiety or depression related to a doubt about one's gender identity or sexual orientation has been classified as sexual maturation disorder by the WHO in the ICD-10, under "Mental and behavioural sicknesses/problems connected with sexual development and orientation". Sexual orientation, by itself, is not an illness and is not classified under this heading. 

[[Viveca Lärn]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, Swedish children's writers

Viveca Lärn, earlier Viveca Sundvall, born 6 April 1944 in Örgryte Parish in Gothenburg, Sweden, is a Swedish writer. and journalist. She is mostly famous for writing the Mimmi and the Eddie children's books series. She has also written books for adults. Her books for adults have led to the TV series Saltön.

[[Bonnot Gang]]

CATEGORIES: Anarchists

The Bonnot Gang was a group of French anarchists known for robbing banks. They were credited with being the first to use the getaway car. They also used repeating rifles, which not even the police had. Their crimes were violent—murder, bank robbery and auto theft. They were known for their belief in illegalism, a school of anarchism that promotes crime. The reasoning was the state had no legitimate authority so they could break any laws they wished. The gang was named after its leader, Jules Bonnot. They were very famous at the time (1911-1912) and have been made into legends through books, television, movies, etc. throughout France and other countries.

[[Barbro Lindgren]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Swedish children's writers

Barbro Lindgren, born 18 March 1937, is a Swedish children's books writer. In 2004, she was awarded the Hans Christian Andersen Award. In 2004, she was awarded the Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award.

[[Tommy Nilsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Erik Tommy Nilsson , born 11 March 1960 in Köping, Sweden is a Swedish rock singer and composer.

[[Tommy Körberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Bert Gustav Tommy Körberg (ˈtɔmːʏ ˈɕɶːrˌbærj), born 4 July 1948 in Norsjö, Sweden is a Swedish singer, actor, and musician. He played the role as Anatoly/"The Russian" in the musical Chess.

[[Claes-Göran Hederström]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Swedish singers

Claes-Göran Hederström, born on 20 October 1945 in Danderyd, Sweden) is a Swedish singer. He made his musical debut at SVT in 1967. He represented Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 1968 with the song Det börjar verka kärlek, banne mej. The song ended up 5th.

[[Smegma]]

CATEGORIES: Exocrine system

Smegma is a substance that forms in the sex organs of mammals. It is made of epithelial cells, skin cells, and moisture. It is found around the foreskin of the penis in males, or in the folds of skin around the vulva in females. In males, the smegma acts like a lubricant which makes sexual intercourse easier. It can be white through to yellow in colour. Smegma does not cause any harm, and normal washing will keep it under control; in fact too much washing may cause other problems.

[[Anna-Lena Löfgren]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2010 deaths, Singers from Stockholm

Anna-Lena Löfgren, born 1 May 1944, dead 21 May 2010, was a singer from Stockholm, Sweden. Between 1962 and 1995, she scored more than 40 Svensktoppen hit songs. During the 1960s, she also scored successes in the German-speaking world.

[[Östen Warnerbring]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2006 deaths, Swedish singers

Östen Warnerbring, born 22 November 1934, died 18 January 2006, was a Swedish singer, musician, composer and lyricist. He represented Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 1967 with the song Som en dröm. The music was written by Marcus Österdahl & Curt Pettersson. The lyrics were written by Patrice Hellberg.

[[Lill Lindfors]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, People from Helsinki, Swedish singers

Maj Lillemor "Lill" Lindfors, born 12 May 1940 in Helsinki, Finland is a Swedish singer. She has performed successful in Scandinavia since the 1960s. Together with Svante Thuresson, she performed the song "Nygammal vals during the Eurovision Song Contest 1966, where Sweden ended up 2nd.

[[Lillemor Arvidsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2012 deaths, Swedish politicians

Maj ''Lillemor'' Arvidsson, born 1 May 1943, dead 23 April 2012, was a Swedish trade union leader. She served as the Governor of Gotland from 1998 to 2004.

[[Selma Lagerlöf]]

CATEGORIES: 1858 births, 1940 deaths, LGBT Nobel Prize winners, LGBT writers, Swedish writers

Selma Ottilia Lovisa Lagerlöf (ˈsɛlˈma ˈlɑːɡə(r)ˈløːv; born 20 November 1858, dead 16 March 1940, was a Swedish writer. In 1909, she was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature becoming the first woman to do so. She is mostly known for her children's book Nils Holgerssons underbara resa genom Sverige (The Wonderful Adventures of Nils). She also worked for women's rights.

[[Yngve Stoor]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 1985 deaths, Swedish singers

Hans ''Yngve'' Stoor, born 5 April 1912 in Stora Kopparberg, Sweden, dead 3 October 1985 in Älvsjö, Sweden, was a Swedish singer, lyricist and composer. One of his most famous recordings is the 1945 Christmas song Sjömansjul på Hawaii.

[[Barnens brevlåda]]

CATEGORIES: Radio programs, 1925 establishments in Sweden, 1972 disestablishments, Companies of Sweden

Barnens brevlåda was a Swedish children's radio programme. It was led by Sven Jerring. It aired totally 1 785 times between 11 September 1925 and 1972. When airing for last time, it was the longest-lasting Swedish radio programme of that time. The record was broken on 14 November 1999 by the programme Smoke Rings.

[[Sven Jerring]]

CATEGORIES: 1895 births, 1979 deaths, Swedish journalists, Swedish radio personalities

Sven Alfred Teodor Jerring (born Jonsson 8 December 1895 in Malung – 27 April 1979 in Stockholm) was a Swedish radio personality. He was active as a presenter, sports journalist and commentator for Sveriges Radio. From 1925, he was the annual Vasaloppet commentator.

[[Ylva Eggehorn]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Christian hymnwriters, Christian writers, Writers from Stockholm, Poets

Ylva Elisabet Eggehorn (born 6 March 1950 in Stockholm) is a Swedish Christian poet, writer, and hymnwriter. She has also written "historical fantasy" books about Gustav Badin.

[[Thomas Hodgkin]]

CATEGORIES: 1798 births, 1866 deaths, English physicians, People from Middlesex, Deaths from dysentery

Thomas Hodgkin (17 August 1798 – 5 April 1866) was an English physician. He was born in Pentonville, Middlesex. He researched many kinds of diseases and discovered Hodgkin's disease. He died of dysentery in Jaffa, Ottoman Syria.

[[Thomas Addison]]

CATEGORIES: 1793 births, 1860 deaths, English physicians, English scientists, People from Northumberland, Suicides by jumping in the United Kingdom

Thomas Addison (April 1793 – 29 June 1860) was an English physician and scientist. 

Addison was born in Longbenton, Northumberland. He discovered Addison's disease and Addison's anemia.

Addison killed himself in Brighton, East Sussex. He jumped from a hospital he worked in. He suffered from depression.

[[Richard Bright (physician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1789 births, 1858 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in England, English physicians, People from Bristol

Richard Bright (28 September 1789 – 16 December 1858) was an English physician. He was born in Bristol. Bright researched many kidney diseases. He discovered Bright's disease. 

Bright died in London from heart disease, aged 69.

[[James Parkinson]]

CATEGORIES: 1755 births, 1824 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in England, Deaths from stroke, English activists, English geologists, English palaeontologists, English physicians, Scientists from London, Pharmacists

James Parkinson FGS (11 April 1755spaced ndash21 December 1824) was an English surgeon, apothecary, geologist, palaeontologist, and political activist. He researched and discovered Parkinson's disease.

Parkinson was born in Shoreditch, London. He died from a stroke in Langthorne, North Riding of Yorkshire, England, aged 69.

[[Jean-Martin Charcot]]

CATEGORIES: 1825 births, 1893 deaths, Neurologists, Scientists from Paris

Jean-Martin Charcot (ʃ; ʃaʁko; 29 November 1825 – 16 August 1893) was a French neurologist and professor of anatomical pathology.  He was known as "the founder of modern neurology". He discovered many diseases such as Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease and Charcot disease (better known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, motor neurone disease, or Lou Gehrig disease).

[[Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, Bankers, Mayors of Warsaw, Polish businesspeople

Hanna Beata Gronkiewicz-Waltz (born 4 December 1952 in Warsaw) is a Polish lawyer, economist, politician. She was president of National Bank of Poland (1992-2001), vicepresident of European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (2001-2004). She is also viceleader of Civic Platform. In 2013 she received full professor title. In 2014 she has been again elected for Mayor of Warsaw. In 2018 she ended her term and did not run for the next one.

[[Pierre Marie]]

CATEGORIES: 1853 births, 1940 deaths, Neurologists, Scientists from Paris

Pierre Marie (9 September 1853 – 13 April 1940) was a French neurologist. He was born in Paris. He was one of the scientists to discover Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

[[Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT), also known as Charcot–Marie–Tooth neuropathy, hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN) and peroneal muscular atrophy (PMA) — is a genetically and clinically heterogeneous group of inherited disorders of the peripheral nervous system characterised by progressive loss of muscle tissue and touch sensation across various parts of the body.

[[Howard Henry Tooth]]

CATEGORIES: 1856 births, 1925 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in England, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage, English scientists, Neurologists

Howard Henry Tooth, CMG, CB (22 April 1856–1925) was a British neurologist. He was one of the scientists who discovered Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Tooth died from a cerebral hemorrhage in Hadleigh, Suffolk, England.

[[Frederic Lewy]]

CATEGORIES: 1885 births, 1950 deaths, Scientists from California, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Neurologists, Scientists from Berlin

Frederic Henry Lewey (born Friedrich Heinrich Lewy, January 28, 1885 - October 5, 1950) was a Jewish German-born American neurologist. He is best known for the discovery of Lewy bodies.

[[Alfons Maria Jakob]]

CATEGORIES: 1884 births, 1931 deaths, German scientists, Neurologists

[[Hans Gerhard Creutzfeldt]]

CATEGORIES: 1885 births, 1964 deaths, German scientists, Neurologists

Hans Gerhard Creutzfeldt (June 2, 1885 – December 30, 1964) was a German neuropathologist. He was the first to describe Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. He was born in Harburg upon Elbe and died in Munich.

[[Dementia with Lewy bodies]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases, Dementia

Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), also known as diffuse Lewy body disease, cortical Lewy body disease, and senile dementia of Lewy type, is a type of dementia accompanied by changes in sleep, behavior, cognition, movement, and automatic bodily functions. It is characterized by the presence of Lewy bodies, parts of  alpha-synuclein and ubiquitin protein in neurons, detectable in post mortem brain histology.

Lewy body dementia affects 1.3 million individuals in the United States alone.

[[Beji Caid Essebsi]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2019 deaths, Presidents of Tunisia, Prime Ministers of Tunisia, Speakers of the Assembly of the Representatives of the People

Mohamed Beji Caid Essebsi (or el-Sebsi, محمد الباجي قائد السبسي, ar; 29 November 1926 – 25 July 2019) was a Tunisian lawyer and politician. He was the fifth President of Tunisia from 2014 until his death in 2019. He was elected in the first presidential election that followed the Tunisian Revolution. From 27 February 2011 to 24 December 2011, he was the Prime Minister of Tunisia.

On 27 June 2019, Essebsi was hospitalized at a military hospital in Tunis under critical condition due to a "severe medical crisis". The following day his condition stabilized. He died a month later on 25 July after being hospitalized after having a "medical scare" in Tunis at the age of 92.

[[Hédi Baccouche]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Prime Ministers of Tunisia

Hédi Baccouche (15 January 1930 – 21 January 2020) was the Prime Minister of Tunisia from 7 November 1987 to 27 September 1989.  Baccouche led the Socialist Destourian Party until it changed its name to the Constitutional Democratic Rally in 1988. He was born in Hammam Sousse.

[[Hamed Karoui]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Prime Ministers of Tunisia

Hamed Karoui (30 December 1927 – 27 March 2020) was Prime Minister of Tunisia from 27 September 1989 to 17 November 1999. From 1986 to 1987 he was Minister of Youth and Sports and from 1988 to 1989 he was Minister of Justice.  He was a member of the Constitutional Democratic Rally party. He was born in Sousse, Tunisia.

Karoui died on 27 March 2020 at his home in Sousse at the age of 92.

[[Mohammed Mzali]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2010 deaths, Prime Ministers of Tunisia

Mohammed Mzali (محمد مزالي, 23 December 1925 – 23 June 2010) was a Tunisian politician. He served as Prime Minister of Tunisia from 23 April 1980 through 8 July 1986. Mzali was born in Monastir, Tunisia.

He served as a member of the International Olympic Committee from 1965 until his death in 2010.

Mzali died in Paris, France from a long-illness, aged 85.

[[Alvin Sargent]]

CATEGORIES: Academy Award winners, 1927 births, 2019 deaths, American screenwriters, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Alvin Sargent (April 12, 1927 – May 9, 2019) was an American screenwriter. He won two Academy Awards in 1978 and 1981 for his screenplays of Julia and Ordinary People. 

Sargent died on May 9, 2019 in Seattle, Washington at the age of 92.

[[Joseph Sargent]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winning directors, 1925 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from cardiovascular disease, American television directors, Movie directors from New Jersey, Movie producers from New Jersey, People from Jersey City, New Jersey

Joseph Sargent (born Giuseppe Danielle Sorgente, July 22, 1925 – December 22, 2014) was an American movie and television director and producer. He was best known for his movies White Lightning, MacArthur, Nightmares, Jaws: The Revenge, and The Taking of Pelham One Two Three. He won four Emmy Awards.

Sargent died of complications from heart disease at his home in Malibu, California, on December 22, 2014. He was 89.

[[Burrill Bernard Crohn]]

CATEGORIES: 1884 births, 1983 deaths, American physicians, Scientists from New York

Burrill B. Crohn (June 13, 1884 – July 29, 1983) was an American gastroenterologist. He was one of the first to describe Crohn's disease. He was born in New York. Crohn died in Connecticut at the age of 99.

[[George Huntington]]

CATEGORIES: 1850 births, 1916 deaths, American physicians, Scientists from New York City

George Huntington (April 9, 1850 – March 3, 1916) was an American physician. He discovered Huntington's disease. He was born in New York City. Huntington died in Long Island, New York, aged 65.

[[Autoimmunity]]

CATEGORIES: Immunology

Autoimunity is immune reaction against self components, which are recognized as antigens. This reaction can produce severe inflammation or can be innocuous, as when directed to intracellular autoantigens, which are not expressed to circulating antibodies or to the lymphocytes.

Autoimunity can develop spontaneously or can be induced experimentally by immunization with autoantigens or antigensd croos-reactive with autoantigens. Autoimunity reactions cause numerous autoimmune diseases and disorders.

[[Muhammed Zafar Iqbal]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people, Bangladeshi writers, People from Dhaka, Bangla Academy Literary Award winners

Muhammed Zafar Iqbal (মুহম্মদ জাফর ইকবাল;  born 23 December 1952) is a Bangladeshi author of science fiction and Children's literature He is a professor of computer science and engineering at Shahjalal University of Science and Technology. He is also head of the department of electrical and electronic engineering at that university. He was fled from war in 1971, but after winning the  liberation war, he came back from the cave and pretend to be a freedom fighter.   

[[Division of Barker]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, South Australia, 1903 establishments in Australia

The Division of Barker is an Australian Electoral Division in the south-east of South Australia. it includes the towns of Barmera, Berri, Bordertown, Keith, Kingston SE, Loxton, Mannum, Millicent, Mount Gambier, Murray Bridge, Naracoorte, Penola, Renmark, Tailem Bend, Waikerie, and parts of Nuriootpa and Tanunda. It was set up in 1903, and named for Collet Barker, who explored the mouth of the Murray River in 1831.

[[Division of Boothby]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, South Australia, 1903 establishments in Australia

The Division of Boothby is an Australian electoral division in South Australia. It was set up 1903 and is named for William Boothby (1829–1903), the Returning Officer for the first federal election in 1901.

It covers the suburbs south of Adelaide, including Aberfoyle Park, Belair, Blackwood, Brighton, Daw Park, Eden Hills, Flagstaff Hill, Marion, Mitcham, Seacliff, St Marys and Panorama.

[[Willie Rennie]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, People from Fife

William Cowan "Willie" Rennie (born 27 September 1967) is a Scottish politician. He is the current Leader of the Scottish Liberal Democrats. He became the Member of Parliament (MP) for Dunfermline and West Fife in February 2006. Rennie lost this seat to Labour in the May 2010 UK general election. He was then appointed as a Special Government Adviser. He  worked for the Scottish Secretaries of State Danny Alexander MP and then Michael Moore MP. He stood for the Scottish Parliament in the 2011 Scottish Parliament general election. He was elected as a member for the Mid Scotland and Fife region. Soon afterwards he was elected as leader of the Scottish Liberal Democrat party. He replaced Tavish Scott.

[[K. Balachander]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2014 deaths, Indian movie directors, Deaths from urinary tract infection, Infectious disease deaths in India, Indian movie producers, Indian screenwriters, Tamil directors

Kailasam Balachander (9 July 1930 – 23 December 2014) was an Indian movie director, screenwriter and producer. He was born in Nannilam, Madras presidency, British India. Balachander was known for directing Neerkumizhi (1965).

Balachander died from a urinary tract infection in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India, aged 84.

[[Gideon Ben-Yisrael]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2014 deaths, Former Members of Knesset, Jewish Israeli politicians, Mapai politicians, People from Haifa

Gideon Ben-Yisrael, Hebrew: גדעון בן-ישראל , (March 6, 1923 – December 18, 2014) was an Israeli politician. He served as a member of the Knesset for Mapai and Rafi in the 1950s and 1960s. He was born in Haifa, Mandatory Palestine.

Ben-Yisrael died in Tel Aviv from natural causes, aged 92. He was buried at the Trumpeldor Cemetery in Tel Aviv.

[[Ronald and Nancy Reagan Research Institute]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 establishments in Illinois, Buildings and structures in Chicago, Illinois, Nancy Reagan, Things named after Ronald Reagan

The Ronald and Nancy Reagan Research Institute, an affiliate of the National Alzheimer's Association in Chicago, Illinois, is an initiative founded by former United States President Ronald Reagan and First Lady Nancy Reagan to accelerate the progress of Alzheimer's disease research. The center was dedicated in 1995.

[[Alsou]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, Living people, Russian singers, Tatarstan

Alsou Ralifovna Abramova (Алсу́ Рали́фовна Абра́мова; Алсу Рәлиф кызы Абрамова; née Safina, born June 27, 1983) is a Bugulman singer. She is known simply as Alsou (Алсу́). She is a Tartar and a Muslim, born in Bugulma (Republic of Tatarstan). Alsou only speaks a few common phrases in her own language. At the age of 15 she gained recognition with her first recording, Alsou. 

She competed in the Eurovision Song Contest 2000 finishing in second place. She also released her first English album in 2000. Alsou hosted the final of the Eurovision Song Contest 2009 held in Moscow. On 7 July 2011 Alsou was appointed as a UNESCO Artist for Peace by Director-General Irina Bokova. She is a founder and organizer of the International Folk Music Festival of Peoples of the Volga River.

[[MTV Unplugged]]

CATEGORIES: Music television series, MTV, Peabody Award winners

MTV Unplugged is a TV series. It showcases many popular musical artists usually playing acoustic instruments. It received the George Foster Peabody Award and 3 Primetime Emmy nominations.

[[Aquilops]]

CATEGORIES: Ceratopsids

Aquilops is a small early Ceratopsian dinosaur from Montana, U.S.A.. It is from the Lower Cretaceous, about 109 to 104 million years ago (mya). This is 20 million years before the previous earliest known North American dinosaur of its type.

The skull, which is the only part found, is smaller than a man's hand.

[[Down (Jay Sean song)]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 songs

"Down" is the first single off British R&B singer Jay Sean's third studio album All or Nothing. The song was released in 31 May 2009 on US radio and on 30 June 2009 through digital retailer. The song also features American rapper Lil Wayne. 

Down would go on to sell four million copies in the United States and six million copies worldwide. It also received a large amount of airplay from two billion listener impressions on radio worldwide.

The song was able to reach #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and overtook The Black Eyed Peas after their 26 week reign at number one. By doing this, it made Jay Sean the first British act to reach a Billboard Hot 100 number-one single since Coldplay's "Viva la Vida" in 2008, as well as the fourth British act overall this decade. It is the best-selling single by a British/European male artist in North America since Elton John's "Candle in the Wind" in 1997,and it is the first by a British Asian artist since Freddie Mercury in 1980.

The song has also been covered by Dutch pop punk band Destine as a stand alone single and by American electronic rock band Breathe Carolina for the compilation album Punk Goes Pop 3.

[[Saydabad District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Afghanistan

Saydabad is the main district of Wardak Province, Afghanistan. There are several villages in the district.

[[Down (Stone Temple Pilots song)]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 songs

"Down" is the first single off American hard rock band Stone Temple Pilots' fourth studio album No. 4. The song was released on April 5, 1999. The song is also featured on STP's compilation albums Thank You and Buy This.

On the Billboard charts, Down was able to peak at #5 on the Mainstream Rock Tracks chart, #7 on the Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles chart and at #9 on the Modern Rock Tracks chart.

In 2001, the song was nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Hard Rock Performance at the 43rd Annual Grammy Awards but it lost to "Guerrilla Radio" by Rage Against the Machine.

[[Angham]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Egyptian singers, People from Alexandria, Record producers

Angham Mohamed Ali Suleiman (أنغام محمد علي سليمان) (born January 19, 1972) is an Egyptan singer, record producer and actress. She is one the most successful Egyptian female singers.

Amr Abdul-Basset Abdul-Azeez Diab (عمرو عبد الباسط عبد العزيز دياب , born 11 October 1961) is an Egyptian singer-songwriter.

[[MTV Unplugged (Julieta Venegas album)]]
