[[Julio Scherer García]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2015 deaths, Deaths from sepsis, Disease-related deaths in Mexico, Mexican journalists, Writers from Mexico City

Julio Scherer García (7 April 1926 – 7 January 2015) was a Mexican author and journalist. He was the editor of the Mexican newspaper Excelsior from 1968 to 1976. He also was the founder of the news magazine Proceso.

Garcia died in Mexico City from  septic shock, aged 88.

[[Bernard Maris]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2015 deaths, French economists, French journalists, French murder victims, Murders by firearm in France, People from Toulouse

Bernard Maris (23 September 1946spaced ndash7 January 2015) was a French economist, writer and journalist. He was also a shareholder in Charlie Hebdo magazine. He was born in Toulouse, France.

Maris was murdered in January 2015, in the Charlie Hebdo shooting at the headquarters of the magazine in Paris.

[[Charlie Hebdo shooting]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 in France, 2015 mass shootings, 2015 murders in Europe, 2010s crimes in France, 2010s in Paris, 2010s mass shootings in Europe, Islamic terrorist incidents in 2015, Islamic terrorist incidents in France, January events, Massacres in Europe, Mass murder in 2015, Mass murder in France, Murder in Paris, Murders by firearm in France, Terrorist incidents in Europe in the 2010s, Terrorist incidents in Paris

On 7 January 2015, at approximately 11:30 CET (10:30 UTC), three masked gunmen armed with Kalashnikov rifles, a shotgun, and a rocket-propelled grenade launcher stormed the headquarters of the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo in Paris. They shot and killed 12 people, including  Charlie Hebdo staff and two French National police officers, and wounded 11 others. In Niger churches and cars were burned in protest of Muhammed on the cover of Charlie Hebdo.

The gunmen entered the building and began shooting with automatic weapons, while shouting "Allahu Akbar". Up to 50 shots were fired during the attack. Following a massive manhunt, the French police believe they have located the attackers and are mounting an operation against them. On Twitter people used the hashtag #JeSuisCharlie to show support for freedom of speech after the shooting.

[[Charlie Hebdo]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 establishments in France, French-language newspapers, Paris

; French for Weekly Charlie) is a French satirical weekly newspaper, featuring cartoons, reports, and jokes. It was founded by Georges Bernier and François Cavanna in 1970.

The stories and cartoons they publish are very left-wing and anarchist, with primarily political satire. Following a long tradition in France, called anti-clericalism, the magazine strongly criticized all religions; it has often published caricatures of Jews, Muslims or Christians (especially Catholics). Some Islamic fundamentalists were offended at some cartoons, and repeatedly sent death threats to the journalists of Charlie Hebdo.

On 7 January 2015, there was a massacre at their office, in which six journalists and cartoonists were killed. This massacre was a shock to millions of people in the world. It was felt to many people like an attack on the freedom of speech, which is an essential part of a democracy.

[[Per-Olof Åstrand]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2015 deaths, Swedish scientists

Per-Olof Åstrand (October 21, 1922 – January 2, 2015) was a Swedish professor of physiology. He worked at the Royal Gymnastic Central Institute (GCI/GIH) in Stockholm 1970-1977, and 1977-1988 at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm, Sweden. He was a member of the Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institutet (1977–1988). Åstrand is considered a "pioneer", "legend" and one of the "founding fathers" of modern exercise physiology.

[[Lance Diamond]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2015 deaths, American radio personalities, Singers from Buffalo, New York

Lance Diamond (c. 1946 — January 4, 2015) was an American lounge singer and radio personality from Buffalo, New York. His career spanned over 40 years.  He often called himself the "Love Doctor," getting the name from his #1 radio show, Saturday Night Fever which he hosted every Saturday night.

Diamond died on January 4, 2015, aged 68, a few days after being hospitalized due to heart complications that prevented him from performing his annual New Year's Eve show. He was unmarried and had no children.

[[Stu Miller]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2015 deaths, St. Louis Cardinals players, Philadelphia Phillies players, San Francisco Giants players, Baltimore Orioles players, Atlanta Braves players, Sportspeople from Massachusetts

Stuart Leonard "Stu" Miller (December 26, 1927 – January 4, 2015) was a former American pitcher in Major League Baseball. He played for the St. Louis Cardinals (1952–1956), Philadelphia Phillies (1956), New York/San Francisco Giants (1957–1962), Baltimore Orioles (1963–1967) and Atlanta Braves (1968). 

He batted and threw right-handed. In a 16-season career, Miller posted a 105–103 record with a 3.24 earned run average, 1164 strikeouts, and 154 saves in 704 games pitched (93 as a starter).

Miller died January 4, 2015, in Cameron Park, California, aged 87 after a brief illness.

[[Vlastimil Bubník]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2015 deaths, Czech footballers, People from Brno

Vlastimil Bubník (ˈvlascɪmɪl ˈbubɲiːk; 18 March 1931 – 6 January 2015) was a Czech ice hockey player and footballer.

Bubník was born in Kelč, Czechoslovakia, and played in the Czechoslovak Extraliga. He played for HC Brno and Královo Pole. He also won a bronze medal at the 1964 Winter Olympics. He was inducted into the International Ice Hockey Federation Hall of Fame in 1997.

[[Joy Ali]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, 2015 deaths, Boxers, Fijian sportspeople

Zulfikar Joy Ali (22 December 1978 – 5 January 2015) was an Indo-Fijian boxer. Ali was once ranked 13th in the world and, in October 2005, was ranked 15th by the WBA in the Super welterweight division. He beat Gary Comers for the PABA title. He was the brother of Junior Farzan Ali.

[[King Sporty]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2015 deaths, Jamaican singers

Noel G. Williams (September 19, 1943 – January 5, 2015), better known as King Sporty, was a Jamaican DJ, reggae musician, and record producer for the Tashamba and Konduko labels. He is best known for writing the song, "Buffalo Soldier", made famous by Bob Marley. He was born in Portland, Jamaica.

Sporty died on January 5, 2015 in Miami, Florida, United States, aged 71.

[[Sentai]]

CATEGORIES: Military of Japan

In Japanese, sentai is a military unit and may be literally translated as squadron, "task force", "group" or "wing". The terms "regiment" and "flotilla", while sometimes used as translations of Sentai, are also used to refer to larger formations. Sentai television series are Live-action shows with young heros in spandex fighting monsters with their martial arts.

[[Khan Bonfils]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, 2015 deaths, Unexplained deaths, British movie actors, British stage actors

Khan Bonflis (Kan Bonflis; c. 1972 – January 5, 2015) was a British actor of Asian origin. He was known for his small roles in Tomorrow Never Dies, Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow, Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace, Batman Begins, and in Skyfall.

Bonflis died while rehearsing for a play in London, aged 42.

[[Jean-Pierre Beltoise]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2015 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Formula One drivers, Sportspeople from Paris

Jean-Pierre Maurice Georges Beltoise (26 April 1937 – 5 January 2015) was a French Grand Prix motorcycle road racer and Formula One driver. He raced for the Matra and BRM teams. François Cevert was his brother-in-law (his wife's brother). He competed in 88 Grands Prix achieving one win and eight podium finishes. He was born in Paris.

Beltoise died at his holiday home in Dakar, Senegal, on 5 January 2015, aged 77, following two strokes .

[[Pino Daniele]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2015 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Italy, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Entertainers from Campania, Guitarists, Singer-songwriters, People from Naples

Pino Daniele (19 March 1955 – 4 January 2015) was an Italian singer-songwriter,  and guitarist. He was born in Naples, Italy. He was known for his songs; Passi d'autore of 2004 and Il Fatto Quotidiano''.

On January 5th, 2015, it was announced via Instagram by Daniele's longtime friend Eros Ramazzotti that he had died from a heart attack between 4 and 5 January. Daniele is considered to have been one of the best singer-songwriters in Italian history. Daniele's death was confirmed at 10:45pm at "Sant'Eugenio" Hospital in Rome (Italy) on 4 January.

[[Philippe Honoré]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2015 deaths, People from Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes, Cartoonists, French artists, French murder victims, Murders by firearm in France

Philippe Honoré (ɔnɔʁe; 25 November 1941 – 7 January 2015), known by the pen-name Honoré, was a French cartoonist. He was born in Vichy, France. Honoré worked with the newspaper company Charlie Hebdo during most of his career. He was a staff cartoonist there.

Honoré died on January 7, 2015, during the January 2015 shooting attack on the Charlie Hebdo newspaper office. 

[[Professeur Choron]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2005 deaths, French comedians

Georges Bernier (21 September 1929 – 10 January 2005), more commonly known as Le Professeur Choron, was a French humorist. He was the founder of Hara Kiri magazine and helped discover Charlie Hebdo, a satirical newspaper.

[[Swiss Chalet]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 establishments in Canada, Canadian restaurants

Swiss Chalet is a Canadian chain of casual dining restaurants. Swiss Chalet was started in 1954 in Toronto, Ontario. The restaurant chain is owned by Cara Operations. Swiss chalet's signature food is rotisserie chicken. Their signature dish is the Quarter Chicken Dinner, either a roasted chicken leg or breast with "Chalet Sauce", a bread roll, and a side dish of the customers choice. Other combinations up to and including a whole chicken are also available.

The first Swiss Chalet restaurant was opened at 234 Bloor Street West in Toronto and it operated for 52 years. This restaurant was closed in 2006 and it was demolished in 2009 to make way for condominiums.

In 2008, Swiss Chalet food products were added to Air Canada to be on their buy-on-board menu.

[[Jethro Pugh]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2015 deaths, American football defensive ends, American football defensive tackles, Dallas Cowboys players, Sportspeople from North Carolina

Jethro Pugh, Jr. (July 3, 1944 – January 7, 2015) was an American football player. He played as a defensive tackle and a defensive end in the National Football League (NFL) for the Dallas Cowboys from 1965 until 1978. Pugh retired on January 29, 1979.

Pugh was born in Windsor, North Carolina. He attended Elizabeth City State University in Elizabeth City, North Carolina.

Pugh died on January 7, 2015 in Dallas, Texas, aged 70.

[[Tim Roberts]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, 2015 deaths, American professional wrestlers, Sportspeople from New York City

Timothy "Tim" Roberts (December 27, 1976 – January 7, 2015), also known by his ring names "The Arsonist" or "El Piromaniaco" Tim Arson, was an American professional wrestler. He made his first wrestling appearance in 2001, and was signed by both WWE and Extreme Championship Wrestling (ECW). He was trained by Johnny Rodz. He competed in shows and tournaments over the United States and Puerto Rico.

Roberts was born in Staten Island, New York City.

Roberts died on January 7, 2015 in Haskell, New Jersey, aged 38.

[[Kep Enderby]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2015 deaths, Australian judges, Australian Labor Party politicians, Politicians from New South Wales

Keppel Earl "Kep" Enderby QC (25 June 1926 – 8 January 2015) was an Australian politician and judge. He was a member of the House of Representatives for the Australian Labor Party between 1970 and 1975. He also became a senior cabinet minister in the Gough Whitlam government. After politics, he was became a Justice of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, serving from 1982 to 1992. He was the president of the Universal Esperanto Association from 1998 to 2001.

Enderby was born in Dubbo, New South Wales. He was married to Dot and lived in Sydney.

Enderby died on 8 January 2015 at the age of 88.

[[Intel Core i5]]

CATEGORIES: Computer processors

Intel Core i5 is a name that Intel uses for the computer processors it makes for desktop and laptop computers. 

The first Core i5 is a version of the earlier Core i7, the Lynnfield core. Lynnfield Core i5 processors have an 8 MB L3 cache. They have a DMI (Direct Media Interface) bus running at 2.5 GT/s. Core i5 also has support for dual-channel DDR SDRAM memory and have Hyper-threading disabled. A new feature called Turbo Boost Technology was introduced which maximizes speed for demanding computer programs. This increases performance to match the amount of work the computer must do.

The Core i5-5xx mobile processors are named Arrandale. They are based on the 32nm Westmere shrink of the Nehalem microarchitecture. Arrandale processors have integrated graphics capability but only two processor cores. They were released in January 2010. Clarkdale, is the desktop version of Arrandale. These are the first processors to have integrated video. It has Hyper-Threading enabled and the full 4 MB L3 cache.

[[Svartbyn]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Norrbotten County

Svartbyn is a locality in Överkalix Municipality, in Norrbotten County in Sweden. In 2010, 265 people lived there.

Vittsjö is a locality in Hässleholm Municipality in Skåne County in Sweden. In 2010, 1,665 people lived there.

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Skane County

Yngsjö is a locality in Kristianstad Municipality in Skåne County in Sweden. In 2010, 302 people lived there. The Yngsjö murder took place here in 1889.

Morgongåva is a locality in Heby Municipality in Uppsala County in Sweden. In 2010, 1,409 people lived there.

[[Saint Peter's Church]]

CATEGORIES: Churches in Stockholm

The Saint Peter's Church (Sankt Peterskyrkan) is church building at Norrmalm in the town of Stockholm in Sweden. It was designed by Erik Lallerstedt. The church was built in the Art Nouveau style 1900-1901.

[[Immanuel Church, Stockholm]]

CATEGORIES: Churches in Stockholm

Immanuel Church (Immanuelskyrkan) is church building located in the central parts of the town of Stockholm in Sweden. The church was designed by Sture Frölén. It was built in 1974. The lot it was built on earlier housed a tram depot at the intersection of Birger Jarlsgatan and Kungstensgatan. 

The entire block consists of offices and a hotel. The block was built between 1970–1974 on behalf of the church. The church has been considered a nice example of 1970s modernist architecture. It is of major historical value according to the Stockholm City Museum. 

[[German Church, Gothenburg]]

CATEGORIES: Church of Sweden churches, Churches in Gothenburg

The German Church (Deutsche Kirche, Tyska kyrkan), also called Christinae Church (Christinae kyrka, Christinenkirche), is a church building in the central parts of the town of Gothenburg in Sweden. It was named after queen Christina of Sweden. The church was opened 1748. It is used by the German Parish of the Church of Sweden in Gothenburg. 

[[Cookie Clicker]]

CATEGORIES: Video games

Cookie Clicker is a JavaScript-based browser video game written by French programmer Julien Thiennot.

The point of the game is to bake cookies as fast as possible. To start the game, a player bakes cookies by clicking on a giant cookie. One cookie is gained each time it is clicked. With sufficient cookies to use as currency, a player can buy items and upgrades that will bake more cookies. They will also increase the number of cookies per click. There is no true end to the game. 

[[German Church, Stockholm]]

CATEGORIES: Churches in Stockholm, Church of Sweden churches

The German Church (Deutsche Kirche, Tyska kyrkan), sometimes called Saint Gertrude's Church (Sankta Gertruds kyrka), is a church in Gamla stan, the old town in central Stockholm in Sweden. It belongs to the German Saint Gertrude Parish of the Church of Sweden.

CATEGORIES: Churches in Sweden, Buildings and structures in Jönköping

The Immanuel Church (Immanuelskyrkan) is a church building at the street of Oxtorgsgatan in the town of Jönköping in Sweden. It belongs to the Uniting Church in Sweden. The church was built in 1975. In 1976, it was opened.

[[Swedish Pentecostal Movement]]

CATEGORIES: Pentecostalism, Protestantism in Sweden, 1900s establishments in Sweden

The Swedish Pentecostal Movement (Pingströrelsen i Sverige) is a Protestant community. On 31 December 2011 it consisted of 463 congregations. Together they make up the Swedish pentecostalism movement. The movement came to Sweden by 1906-1907.

[[Philadelphia Church]]

CATEGORIES: Churches in Stockholm

The Philadelphia Church (Filadelfiakyrkan) is a church building at Rörstrandsgatan 7 in the town of Stockholm in Sweden. It belongs to the Swedish Pentecostal Movement. The church was inaugurated on 2 November 1930.

[[Statistics Sweden]]

CATEGORIES: Sweden, Government agencies, Statistics, 1858 establishments in Europe, 19th century establishments in Sweden

Statistics Sweden (Statistiska centralbyrån, SCB) is the Swedish government agency that makes the official statistics for Sweden. National statistics in Sweden were first created in 1686 when the Church of Sweden was told to start keeping records on the population. Before the SBC, the Office of Tables (Tabellverket), was set up in 1749. The current name was changed in 1858.

Since 2008, the agency had about 1,400 employees. The offices of the agency are in Stockholm and Örebro. Statistics Sweden prints the Journal of Official Statistics.

[[Garphyttan]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Orebro County

Garphyttan is a locality in Örebro Municipality in Örebro County in Sweden. In 2010, 1,619 people lived there. The locality is located 16 kilometers northwest of the town of Örebro. It is located near the Garphyttan National Park.

[[Media franchise]]

CATEGORIES: Media franchises

A media franchise is a collection of related media, usually in a series based on an original work. This can be as movies, books, television programs, or video games. It generally involves the licensing of intellectual property (IP) to other parties and partners. This is for usually for the purpose of selling related goods. Basically a media franchise is a brand. Valuable franchises can sometimes be worth more than the original product. 

A transmedia franchise or multimedia franchise is a kind of media franchise. It consists of cross-marketing across more than one type of medium. An example is American Idol. From the start it was a transmedia franchise. The season-one winner was Kelly Clarkson. She was signed to RCA Records and her first release was an immediate hit. An American Idol book made the bestseller list. American idol contestants went on a nationwide tour and played to sold-out Concert halls. There was even an American idol movie From Justin to Kelly.

[[Grythyttan]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Orebro County

Grythyttan is a locality in Hällefors Municipality in Örebro County in Sweden. In 2010, 891 people lived there.

[[Seventh-day Adventist Church in Sweden]]

CATEGORIES: 1880 establishments in Europe, Protestantism in Sweden, 1880s establishments in Sweden

The Seventh-day Adventist Church in Sweden (Adventistsamfundet i Sverige) is a Seventh-day Adventist denomination in Sweden. The first Seventh-day Adventist Church congregation in Sweden was established in Grythyttan in 1880. Circa 40 Swedish Seventh-day Adventist denominations were around in Sweden during the early 2000s. Most of them existed in Central Sweden.

[[Christian Council of Sweden]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 establishments in Sweden, Christianity in Sweden

The Christian Council of Sweden (Sveriges kristna råd) is an echumenical Christian organization in Sweden. It was established on 15 December 1992.

[[Canada men's national ice hockey team]]

CATEGORIES: National ice hockey teams, Ice hockey in Canada, 1963 establishments in North America, 1960s establishments in Canada

The Canadian National Men's Ice Hockey Team (also known as Team Canada) is the ice hockey team for Canada. The team is run by Hockey Canada, a member of the International Ice Hockey Federation. From 1920 until 1963 Canada did not have a single national hockey team. Instead, senior amateur club teams played for Canada . Canada's national men's team was created in 1963 by Father David Bauer as a part of the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association. This team played out of the University of British Columbia. During the 1972 Summit Series, the name "Team Canada" was first used. The Canadian national team is now often called "Team Canada".

Team Canada has been one of the leading national ice hockey teams playing around the world. They won the 1972 Summit Series against the Soviet Union, four of five Canada Cups since 1976, nine Olympic gold medals (the most of any hockey nation); Salt Lake City 2002, Vancouver 2010, and Sochi 2014. They are 25-time IIHF World Champions and winner of the 2004 World Cup of Hockey.

[[David Rolfe (swimmer)]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 deaths, 1964 births, Australian Paralympic bronze medalists, Australian swimmers, Deaths from surgical complications, Sportspeople from New South Wales

David John Rolfe (26 June 1964 – 7 January 2015) was an Australian swimmer and Paralympian. He won a bronze medal at the 2000 Summer Paralympics in the Men's 4x100 m Medley 34 pts event in Sydney.

Rolfe was born in Inverell, New South Wales. He was married with one child and lived on the Gold Coast in Queensland.

Rolfe died from complications relating to heart surgery on 7 January 2015 on the Gold Coast. He was 50.

[[Lethal Weapon 4]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s action movies, 1990s comedy movies, 1998 movies, English-language movies, Warner Bros. movies

Lethal Weapon 4 is a 1998 comedy-action movie. Danny Glover plays Roger. Mel Gibson plays Martin. Rene Russo plays Lorna Cole. Chris Rock plays Lee.

This movie was released in July 1998. It got mixed to negative reviews from critics. However, it made about $285 million.

[[Lethal Weapon 3]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 action movies, 1992 comedy movies, 1992 movies, Warner Bros. movies

Lethal Weapon 3 is a 1992 comedy-action movie. Rene Russo plays Lorna Cole. Danny Glover plays Roger. Joe Pesci plays Leo. Mel Gibson plays Martin.

This movie was released on May 15, 1992. It got mixed reviews. It made over US$320 million.

[[Bonnie]]

CATEGORIES: Given names

Bonnie is a given name. It is usually used for females. Some males also have the name. It comes from the Scottish word "bonnie", which means pretty or attractive. There are several celebrities with the name, including Bonnie Franklin and Bonnie Raitt.

[[Tadeusz Konwicki]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2015 deaths, Polish movie directors, Polish screenwriters

Tadeusz Konwicki (22 June 1926 – 7 January 2015) was a Polish screenwriter and movie director. He was a member of the Polish Language Council. He was known for his movies A Tale of Adam Mickiewicz's 'Forefathers' Eve, Kronika wypadków milosnych and Mother Joan of the Angels. Konwicki was born in present day Naujoji Vilnia, Lithuania.

Konwicki died in Warsaw, Poland, aged 88.

[[Staryl C. Austin]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2015 deaths, American military people, People from Oregon

Staryl Chester Austin, Jr. (September 16, 1920 – January 1, 2015) was an American brigadier general in the United States Air Force. He was a former Assistant Adjutant General of Oregon and 142nd Fighter Group’s Air Officer, Chief of the Administrative Division. He was a member of the Oregon Aviation Hall of Honor.

[[Andraé Crouch]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2015 deaths, African-American singers, American Christians, American gospel musicians, American record producers, Singer-songwriters from California, Christian clergy, American gospel singers, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Gospel Music Hall of Fame inductees, Grammy Award winners, Musicians from San Francisco

Andraé Edward Crouch (July 1, 1942 – January 8, 2015) was an American gospel singer, songwriter, arranger, recording artist, record producer, and pastor. He was known for his compositions The Blood Will Never Lose Its Power, My Tribute (To God Be the Glory), and Soon and Very Soon.  In the 1980s, he led choirs that sang on the Michael Jackson hit Man in the Mirror as well as Madonna's Like a Prayer.

Crouch was born in San Francisco, California. He was co-pastor at the Christ Memorial Church in Pacoima, Los Angeles with his twin sister, Sandra.

Crouch died from a heart attack on January 8, 2015 in Los Angeles, California, aged 72.

[[Jan Olszewski]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2019 deaths, Politicians from Warsaw, Prime Ministers of Poland

Jan Ferdynand Olszewski AUD (20 August 1930 in Warsaw – 7 February 2019 in Warsaw) was a Polish lawyer and political figure. He is best known for serving as Prime Minister of the Republic of Poland from 1991 to 1992.

Olszewski died after a long illness on 7 February 2019 in a Warsaw hospital, aged 88.

[[Józef Oleksy]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2015 deaths, Cancer deaths in Poland, Prime Ministers of Poland, Marshals of the Sejm

Józef Oleksy (22 June 1946 – 9 January 2015) was a Polish left-wing politician and economist. He served as the seventh Prime Minister of Poland from 7 March 1995 until 7 February 1996. He was also the former chairman of the Democratic Left Alliance (Sojusz Lewicy Demokratycznej, SLD). From 1968 to 1990, he was a member of the communist Polish United Workers' Party.

Oleksy was born in Nowy Sącz, Lesser Poland Voivodeship. He was an atheist before becoming a Roman Catholic.December 2015

Oleksy died from cancer on 9 January 2015 in Warsaw, aged 68.

[[Mompati Merafhe]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2015 deaths, Botswana politicians, Vice Presidents of Botswana

Lt. Gen. Mompati Sebogodi Merafhe (6 June 1936 – 7 January 2015) was a Botswanan politician. He was Vice-President of Botswana from 2008 to 2012. He was a Lieutenant-General and was Botswana's Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1994 to 2008.

[[B. S. Abdur Rahman]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2015 deaths, Indian businesspeople, Indian educators, Indian philanthropists

Buhari Syed Abdur Rahman (15 October 1927 – 7 January 2015) was an Indian serial entrepreneur, philanthropist and educator. He had a range of business interests in the UAE and India. He was one of the 24 Indians to feature in The 500 Most Influential Muslims. Rahman was the Vice-chairman of Emirates Trading Agency from 1973 to 2015. He was the founder of B. S. Abdur Rahman University. Rahman was born in Kilakarai, Madras State, British India.

Rahman died in Chennai, India, aged 87.

[[Theo van Gogh]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2004 deaths, Dutch columnists, Dutch movie actors, Dutch movie directors, Dutch movie producers, Dutch murder victims, Dutch television actors, Islamophobia, People murdered in the Netherlands, Writers from The Hague

Theodoor "Theo" van Gogh (ˈteːjoː vɑŋ ˈɣɔx; 23 July 1957spaced ndash2 November 2004) was a Dutch movie director, movie producer, columnist, author and actor. He was born in The Hague, Netherlands. His great-great uncle was artist Vincent van Gogh. 

[[Elsa Cayat]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s births, 2015 deaths, French journalists, French murder victims, French scientists, Murders by firearm in France, Writers from Paris

Elsa Cayat (ɛlza kaja) (9 March 1960 – 7 January 2015) was a French psychoanalyst and columnist. She had a biweekly column "Le Divan" ('"The Couch") in Charlie Hebdo. The column was based on facts she hated about society. Cayat was also the author of several works on the couple and sexuality, one with the participation of Antonio Fischetti, physics teacher and researcher.

Cayat died in the January 2015 shooting attack on the Charlie Hebdo newspaper offices in Paris, aged 54.

[[Tihomir Novakov]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2015 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Serbian people, American physicists, Scientists from California

Tihomir Novakov, Ph.D known also as Tica Novakov (March 16, 1929 – January 2, 2015) was an Serbian-born American physicist. As a scientist, Novakov was known for his black carbon, air quality, and climate change research. James Hansen dubbed him "the godfather of black carbon." He was born in Sombor, Serbia.

Novakov died on January 2, 2015 in Kensington, California from natural causes, aged 85.

[[Kiruna Church]]

CATEGORIES: Church of Sweden churches

Kiruna Church (Kiruna kyrka) is a church building in the town of Kiruna in Sweden. It was built in the early 20th century. The church belongs to the Jukkasjärvi Parish of the Church of Sweden. It was opened on 8 December 1912 by bishop Olof Bergqvist.

[[Ray McFall]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2015 deaths, The Beatles, English businesspeople, People from Liverpool

Andrew Raymond "Ray" McFall (26 November 1926 – 8 January 2015) was a British businessman. He owned The Cavern Club in Liverpool and was well known for promoting The Beatles during the early 1960s.

McFall was born in Garston, south Liverpool. He married Shirley Wilkins in 1952, and had six children with her: three sons and three daughters. He retired in 1999.

McFall died on 8 January 2015 at the age of 88.

[[Joseph Djida]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2015 deaths, Cameroonian people, Roman Catholic bishops

Joseph Djida OMI (8 April 1945 – 6 January 2015) was a Cameroonian Roman Catholic bishop. He became a priest on 5 December 1976. He was appointed the second bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Ngaoundéré on 23 October 2000.

[[Umeå City Church]]

CATEGORIES: Church of Sweden churches, Umeå

Umeå City Church (Umeå stads kyrka) is a church building in the central parts of Umeå in Sweden. It is located between Vänortsparken and the northern bank of the Ume River. The church belongs to the Umeå City Parish of the Church of Sweden. It was inaugurated on 2 December 1894. That day was First Advent Sunday the same year year.

[[Mizda]]

CATEGORIES: Libya, Towns in Africa

Mizda or Mesdah (مزدة Mizdah) is a town in the Jabal al Gharbi District in Libya. It was the capital of the former Mizda District. 

Just to the west of Mizda is the Mizda Army Base at 31

[[Emily Lloyd]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from London, English movie actors, English television actors, 1970 births, Living people

Emily Lloyd (born 29 September 1970) is an English actress. She played Emily in Wish You Were Here. She played Samantha Hughes in In Country. She also played Cookie in the movie Cookie.

She was born in London, England. Her father was Roger Lloyd-Pack. Her grandfather was Charles Lloyd-Pack.

Vittangi is a locality in Kiruna Municipality in Norrbotten County in Sweden. In 2010, 784 people lived there.

[[Jukkasjärvi]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Norrbotten County

Jukkasjärvi jʊkɑsjɛrvi is a locality in Kiruna Municipality in Norrbotten County in Sweden. In 2010, 548 people lived there.

[[Karesuando]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Norrbotten County

Karesuando (Kaaresuvanto or Karesuvanto, Sami: Karesuanto, Gárasavvon or Karasavvon) is a locality in Kiruna Municipality in Norrbotten County in Sweden. It is the northernmost locality in Sweden. In 2010, 303 people lived there. In 2011, 350 people lived there.

[[Lara Fabian]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, People from Brussels-Capital Region, Canadian singers, Musicians from Brussels

Lara Fabian (born January 9, 1970) is a Belgian singer. She has sold more than twenty million records worldwide. She sings in French, Spanish, English and other languages.

Fabian was born in Etterbeek, Brussels, Belgium to a Sicilian mother and Belgian father.

[[Robert Cunning]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, Scottish footballers, 1983 deaths, Fife

Robert 'Bobby' Robertson Innes Cunning (12 February 1930 – 24 January 1983) was a footballer from Scotland. Cunning was born on 12 February 1930 in Dunfermline, Scotland. He played for Sunderland, Hamilton and the Rangers football clubs. He was a striker.

In 1951, Cunning was on the Sunderland roster playing outside left. In 1952 and 1953, he was on the Hamilton roster. In the 1953/54 season, he played 19 games and scored 2 goals for Hamilton. In 1954, he signed to the Rangers for £2,500. His first match for Rangers was against Clyde in the Glasgow Cup. This was on 9 September 1954 when he was 24. Cunning played seven games for the Rangers. His vision problems ended his career. Cunning died 24 January, 1983 in Dunoon, Scotland.

[[Brian Leetch]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, American ice hockey players, Boston Bruins players, Calder Trophy winners, Conn Smythe Trophy winners, Hockey Hall of Fame inductees, Living people, New York Rangers players, James Norris Memorial Trophy winners, People from Corpus Christi, Texas, Stanley Cup champions, Toronto Maple Leafs players, Ice hockey defencemen

Brian Joseph Leetch (born January 18, 1961) is an American retired professional ice hockey defenseman. He played 18 seasons in the National Hockey League (NHL). He played for the New York Rangers, Toronto Maple Leafs, and Boston Bruins.

He was the winner of the James Norris Memorial Trophy in 1992 and 1997. He won the Stanley Cup with the Rangers in 1994. He also won the Conn Smythe Trophy, becoming the first American-born player to win the trophy. He won the silver medal with U.S. ice hockey team at the 2002 Winter Olympics.

He was inducted into the United States Hockey Hall of Fame with his Rangers teammate Mike Richter in 2008. He was also inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame during his first year of eligibility in 2009.

[[Julia Archibald Holmes]]

CATEGORIES: 1838 births, 1887 deaths, American journalists

Julia Anna Archibald Holmes (February 15, 1838 – January 19, 1887) was a Canadian-American suffragist, abolitionist, mountaineer and journalist. She was the first woman to climb Pikes Peak.

[[Stockholm metro]]

CATEGORIES: Stockholm, Transport in Sweden, Rapid transit systems

The Stockholm metro (Stockholms tunnelbana) is a metro system in Stockholm in Sweden. The first line was opened in 1950. However, underground trams had been used since 1933. The system has 100 stations in use, 47 of them are underground and 53 above ground. There are three lines (Green, Red and Blue) travelling through  Central Stockholm. In the year of 2013 the Stockholm metro cars totally carried 328 million passengers inside. It corresponds to approximately 898,630 passengers per day.

The 105.7 long metro system is owned by the Stockholm County Council through Storstockholms Lokaltrafik (SL). The operation is currently contracted to MTR Corporation.

The Stockholm metro system has been referred to as the"world's longest art gallery", with more over 90 of the network's 100 stations being decorated with various works of art.

[[Ringwoodite]]

CATEGORIES: Minerals

Ringwoodite is a mineral. It is a type of olivine which is formed at high temperatures and pressures in the Earth's mantle between 525 and 660 km deep. Olivine is a magnesium iron silicate. This mineral was first identified in a meteorite in 1969. It may be present in large quantity in the Earth’s mantle.

Ringwoodite is notable because to contains hydroxide ions (oxygen and hydrogen atoms bound together) in its structure. This suggests that there is from one to three times the world ocean's equivalent of water in the mantle's transition zone from 410 to 660 km deep.

[[Roger Kitter]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2015 deaths, Deaths from cancer of unknown primary origin, Cancer deaths in London, British movie actors, British television actors, British stage actors

Roger Kitter (20 October 1949 – 3 January 2015) was a British actor. He was known for his role as 'Allo 'Allo!. In September 2009, he became Chairman of the Entertainment Artistes' Benevolent Fund.

Kitter died from cancer in London of cancer of unknown primary origin at the age of 65.

[[Fungi imperfecti]]

CATEGORIES: Fungi

The fungi imperfecti or imperfect fungi, also known as Deuteromycota, is a type of fungi. It is not a taxonomic category: they are linked only by their asexuality. The taxonomy of fungi is either based on morphological characteristics (what they look like), or that of biological species. Fungi imperfecti do not fit well into these schemes. 

Deueromycota literally means "second fungi", and was once a phylum within the fungi. The fungi in deuteromycota reproduce asexually, or vegetatively: sexual reproduction has never been observed in these species. The term is now used only informally for species of fungi that are asexually reproducing members of the fungal phyla Ascomycota and Basidiomycota.

There are about 25,000 species that have been classified in the deuteromycota and many are basidiomycota or ascomycota. Fungi producing the antibiotic penicillin and those that cause athlete's foot and yeast infections are imperfect fungi. In addition, there are a number of edible imperfect fungi, including the ones that provide the distinctive characteristics of Roquefort and Camembert cheese. Some fungi which are used to develop immunosuppressant drugs, are imperfect fungi. Other imperfect fungi are used for insect pest control. 

Other, more informal, names besides Deuteromycota ("Deuteromycetes") and fungi imperfecti, are  anamorphic fungi, or mitosporic fungi. None of these names are terms of taxonomic rank. They are convenience terms.

[[Akikan!]]

CATEGORIES: Anime characters, Manga

Akikan! is a Japanese manga novel series. It is about a group of anthropomorphic drink cans who do battle. It was created by Riku Ranjō, with illustrations by Hiro Suzuhira. She is known for her artistry in Shuffle!. The first novel was released on May 24, 2007. As of April 24, 2009, eight volumes have been published by Shueisha under their Super Dash Bunko label. In 2008 a project started to create a harem anime version based on the book.

[[Danny Dunton]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2015 deaths, English businesspeople, Sportspeople from Buckinghamshire

Dennis Clifford "Danny" Dunton (13 May 1924 – 2 January 2015) was an English international motorcycle speedway rider and promoter. He reached the final of the Speedway World Championship in 1950, achieving 12th place with 5 points. As well as riding, Danny promoted Peterborough Panthers and co-promoted Oxford Cheetahs, then Oxford Rebels and finally White City Rebels. Dunton was born in Cholesbury, Buckinghamshire.

Dunton died after a long illness on 2 January 2015, aged 90.

[[Concealed weapon]]

CATEGORIES: Weapons

A concealed weapon is a dangerous weapon that is carried by a person and is hidden from view. It can also be a dangerous weapon under a person's control that is not readily visible. The term is most often applied to handguns. A dangerous weapon is any weapon that can inflict death or serious injury on another person. Various jurisdictions define what a dangerous weapon is. Carrying a concealed weapon is illegal as defined by laws of many states, provinces, and countries. The usual exceptions are law enforcement officers and members of the military who carry weapons as part of their jobs. Many jurisdictions may issue concealed weapons permits (also called concealed carry permits) giving individuals permission to carry a concealed weapon within their jurisdiction.

[[Ron Hovey]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2015 deaths, Australian rules footballers, Order of Australia

Ron Hovey OAM (25 August 1932 – 6 January 2015) was an Australian rules footballer. He played with Geelong in the Victorian Football League (VFL) from 1951 until 1960. He later served as the President of Geelong Football Club from 1988 until 1998. Two of his brothers, Ced and Jim, also played league football for Geelong.

Hovey died on 6 January 2015 at the age of 82.

[[Kenneth Mapp]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, Governors of the United States Virgin Islands, Politicians from New York City, Independent politicians in the United States, Lieutenant Governors of the United States Virgin Islands

Kenneth E. Mapp (born November 2, 1955) is an American politician. He was the 29th Governor of the United States Virgin Islands from 2015 to 2019. He is a registered Republican, but ran as an independent.

A former three term Virgin Islands Senator, Mapp served as the Lieutenant Governor of the United States Virgin Islands from 1995 until 1999. Mapp was an independent candidate for Governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands in the 2010 gubernatorial election, but was defeated by  John de Jongh.

He ran in the 2014 gubernatorial election for Governor of the United States Virgin Islands, defeating Donna Christian-Christensen, the longtime Delegate to Congress in a run-off.

[[Gina Raimondo]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, Living people, Governors of Rhode Island, United States Secretaries of Commerce, Businesspeople from Rhode Island, US Democratic Party politicians, Women politicians

Gina Marie Raimondo (born May 17, 1971) is an American politician, businesswoman, and venture capitalist. She is a member of the Democratic Party. In 2021, she became the United States Secretary of Commerce under the Joe Biden administration.

In 2015, Raimondo became the 75th Governor of the State of Rhode Island. She is the first woman to be Governor of Rhode Island. She was the General Treasurer for the State of Rhode Island from 2011 through 2015.

On January 7, 2021, President-elect Joe Biden nominated Raimondo to serve as the United States Secretary of Commerce in his cabinet. Her nomination was confirmed by the United States Senate on March 2, 2021 with a 84-15 vote.

[[Pete Ricketts]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Governors of Nebraska, Businesspeople from Nebraska, US Republican Party politicians

John Peter "Pete" Ricketts (born August 19, 1964) is the 40th and current Governor of Nebraska and former Chief Operating Officer of Ameritrade.

He was the Republican nominee for the 2006 U.S. Senate race in Nebraska, which he lost to then incumbent Ben Nelson. He ran for Governor of Nebraska in the 2014 election, this time defeating the Democratic nominee, Chuck Hassebrook. He was inaugurated as Governor in January 2015.

[[Charlie Baker]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, American Calvinists, Congregationalists, Governors of Massachusetts, Harvard University alumni, Politicians from New York, Businesspeople from New York, Businesspeople from Massachusetts, US Republican Party politicians

Charles Duane "Charlie" Baker, Jr. (born November 13, 1956) is an American businessman and politician. He is the 72nd and current Governor of Massachusetts, since 2015. He was a cabinet official under two Massachusetts governors, spent ten years as CEO of Harvard Pilgrim Health Care. He was also the Republican nominee for Governor of Massachusetts in his unsuccessful bid in 2010.

[[Doug Ducey]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Governors of Arizona, US Republican Party politicians, Politicians from Ohio, People from Toledo, Ohio

Douglas A. "Doug" Ducey (born April 9, 1964) is the 23rd and current Governor of the U.S. State of Arizona. He is a member of the Republican Party, and was sworn in as Governor on January 5, 2015. He also served as the 32nd State Treasurer of Arizona.

[[Susan Howard]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from Texas, American movie actors, American television actors, Writers from Texas, 1944 births, Living people

Jeri Lynn Mooney (born January 28, 1944), also known as Susan Howard, is an American actress and writer. She works in both movies and television series. She played Maggie in Petrocelli. She played Donna in Dallas from 1979 to 1987. In The Love Boat, she played Cynthia.

Mooney was born in Marshall, Texas.

[[Lance Percival]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2015 deaths, English movie actors, English television actors, English voice actors, Comedians from Kent, Actors from Kent

John Lancelot Blades Percival, known as Lance Percival (26 July 1933 – 6 January 2015), was an English actor, comedian and after-dinner speaker. He was known for making the voices of Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr in the animated series The Beatles.

Percival died in January 2015, aged 81. He will be cremated at Putney Vale Cemetery on 20 January 2015.

[[Marshall, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, County seats in Texas

Marshall is a city in northeastern Texas. At the 2010 census, 23,523 people lived there.
